title: libimqutil.so: libc.so.1: cannot open shared object file
body:
We run RedHAt AS 3 on Sun AMD64 servers in production.

I am using Open Message Queue 4.1

An error occured configuring the logging system: java.lang.UnsatisfiedLinkError:
/u01/work/openmq/mq/lib/libimqutil.so: libc.so.1: cannot open shared object
file: No such file or directory

ldd libimqutil.so
libc.so.1 => not found

I have reproduced the problem on our RedHat AS3 production environment and my
Fedora Core 6 environment.

If I create a symlink of libc.so.1 -> libc-2.5.so and do

ldd libimqutil.so

I then get

./libimqutil.so: /lib64/libc.so.1: version `SUNW_1.1' not found (required by
./libimqutil.so)
libc.so.1 => /lib64/libc.so.1 (0x00002aaaaaad6000)
/lib64/ld-linux-x86-64.so.2 (0x0000555555554000)

Not sure what is going on here, but it looks like MQ is not usable on any common
linux system.
#### Environment
Operating System: Linux
Platform: Sun
#### Affected Versions
[current]

title: NA
body:
@glassfishrobot Commented 
lindaschneider@java.net said:
libimqutil.so provides support for native integration on solaris and support
functionality like support for syslog, the ability to hide a password when it is
being typed in, the ability . At this point that type of integration with the
native logging system is not provided for linux. The library has not been ported
to linux.

On linux you should not have a limimqutil.so (if you do, you may have a solaris
install and should remove the native libraries)

However, the inability to load libimqutil.so should not affect the ability of
the product to run on other platforms. (the features supplied such as native
logging will not be available). It may generate a logging message but should not
cause a failure.

If you are unable to start or run the server on Linux you are probably running
into a seperate issue. (it is tested on several flavors of linux)

Can you attach the log file ?

[24/Jan/2007:11:21:07 EST] IMQ_HOME=/u01/work/openmqold/mq
[24/Jan/2007:11:21:07 EST] IMQ_VARHOME=/u01/work/openmqold/mq/var
[24/Jan/2007:11:21:07 EST] Linux 2.6.18-1.2849.fc6 amd64 developer249.office.lan (1 cpu) gluck
[24/Jan/2007:11:21:07 EST] Java Heap Size: max=190080k, current=31680k
[24/Jan/2007:11:21:07 EST] Arguments:
[24/Jan/2007:11:21:07 EST] [B1060]: Loading persistent data...
[24/Jan/2007:11:21:07 EST] Using built-in file-based persistent store: /u01/work/openmqold/mq/var/
instances/imqbroker/
[24/Jan/2007:11:21:08 EST] [B1039]: Broker "imqbroker@developer249.office.lan:7676" ready.

It also does not come with a liqimqutil.so. The shared objects it does come with appear valid. For
example:

ldd libnss3.so
linux-gate.so.1 => (0xffffe000)
libsoftokn3.so (0xf7f46000)
libplc4.so (0xf7f41000)
libplds4.so (0xf7f3e000)
libnspr4.so (0xf7f0c000)
libpthread.so.0 => /lib/libpthread.so.0 (0xf7ede000)
libdl.so.2 => /lib/libdl.so.2 (0xf7eda000)
libc.so.6 => /lib/libc.so.6 (0xf7d9d000)
/lib/ld-linux.so.2 (0x56555000)

Comparid this to 4.1, I get:

ldd libnss3.so
./libnss3.so: /lib64/libc.so.1: version `SUNW_0.7' not found (required by ./libnss3.so)
/usr/bin/ldd: line 116: 13942 Segmentation fault LD_TRACE_LOADED_OBJECTS=1 LD_WARN=
LD_BIND_NOW= LD_LIBRARY_VERSION=$verify_out LD_VERBOSE= "$@"

So, in summary it looks like this bug is:

1\. You should not be packaging solaris only shared objects with the Linux version of mq
2\. The shared objects that should be packaged in the linux version are wrong - maybe solaris versions
based on the SUNW_0.7 error that comes up
3\. We run on amd64\. There is an amd64 subdirectory in bin and lib. What are we supposed to do here?
Copy those binaries over the top of those in the bin and lib directories?
4\. You should have linux specific release notes informing the user of the facilities that are not included.

If you have a lib/amd64 subdir in your distribution, then it most likely is the

directory. We do not install a libimqutil.so for linux.

I don't have 4.1 B17 around but my 4.1 B35 and 4.1 B36 linux builds do not
contain lib/amd64 nor a lib/libimqutil.so.

latest build. It could've been a bad linux bundle that was named incorrectly.

jill

title: Initscript is not compatibile with chkconfig
body:
Hi,

I just found out that mq/src/solaris/etc/imq-linux.sh included information that
supposed to help integration with the chkconfig tool:

#!/bin/sh
#

1.  imq This starts and stops the MQ Broker
    #
2.  chkconfig: 35 52 15

However chkconfig needs at least one additional line in the begining of the
script to work correctly. You should modify the file like:

#!/bin/sh
#

1.  imq This starts and stops the MQ Broker
    #
2.  chkconfig: 35 52 15
3.  description: Message Queue
    #

This way the script can be handeled by chkconfig.

Small issue, I know, but it might help ![](https://java.net/jira/images/icons/emoticons/tongue.gif)
#### Environment
Operating System: Linux
Platform: PC
#### Affected Versions
[current]

title: imqadmin startup script error
body:
Hi,

The imqadmin startup script installed with glassfish generates
IMQ_DEFAULT_VARHOME as an argument to the java class, while it should export it
using bash.

Instead of:

/usr/lib/jvm/java-1.5.0-sun-1.5.0.13/bin/java -cp
./../lib/imqadmin.jar:./../lib/fscontext.jar:./../lib/jhall.jar:./../lib/help:/opt/SUNWhadb/4/lib/hadbjdbc4.jar:/opt/SUNWjavadb/derby.jar
-Dimq.home=./.. -Dimq.varhome=./../var -Dimq.libhome=./../lib
com.sun.messaging.jmq.admin.apps.console.AdminConsole
IMQ_DEFAULT_VARHOME=/home/sanne/glassfish-v2/domains/domain1/imq

it should be:

export IMQ_DEFAULT_VARHOME=/home/sanne/glassfish-v2/domains/domain1/imq

/usr/lib/jvm/java-1.5.0-sun-1.5.0.13/bin/java -cp
./../lib/imqadmin.jar:./../lib/fscontext.jar:./../lib/jhall.jar:./../lib/help:/opt/SUNWhadb/4/lib/hadbjdbc4.jar:/opt/SUNWjavadb/derby.jar
-Dimq.home=./.. -Dimq.varhome=./../var -Dimq.libhome=./../lib
com.sun.messaging.jmq.admin.apps.console.AdminConsole
#### Environment
Operating System: Linux
Platform: All
#### Affected Versions
[current]

title: NA
body:
@glassfishrobot Commented 
jnakata@java.net said:
Hi,

The imqadmin script in GF sources ../lib/imqinit which then sources
../etc/imqenv.conf.
My imqenv.conf has this value set:
IMQ_DEFAULT_VARHOME=/home/nakata/SUNWappserver/domains/domain1/imq

imqinit takes that value and sets it to $imq_varhome.

My command then uses the imq_varhome value correctly without the need
of an "export". Since the scripts fork the shell script the environments
stays within the shell.

My final command is:
/home/nakata/SUNWappserver/jdk/bin/java -cp
./../lib/imqadmin.jar:./../lib/fscontext.jar:/usr/j2se/opt/javahelp/lib/jhall.jar:./../lib/help:/home/nakata/SUNWappserver/hadb/4/lib/hadbjdbc4.jar
-Dimq.home=./.. -Dimq.varhome=/home/nakata/SUNWappserver/domains/domain1/imq
-Dimq.libhome=./../lib com.sun.messaging.jmq.admin.apps.console.AdminConsole

and you can see imq.varhome uses $imq_varhome which is the correct value.

The "export" is only needed if that value is needed outside the imqadmin shell
which it isn't. It is only needed within the imqadmin script.

Perhaps you can double check your values in imq/etc/imqenv.conf or echo values
within imq/lib/imqinit and imq/bin/imqadmin.

thanks,
jill

title: ClassCastException in ConnectionFactoryAdapter when creating TopicConnection under OC4J
body:
I've been trying to deploy the openMQ resource adapter to OC4J 10.1.3\. After
some effort the addapter seems to deploy allright, but when a web app tries to
access a TopicConnection from the adapter via JNDI I consitently get a
ClassCastException on line 282 of ConnectionFactory Addapter (in
_allocateTopicConnection()). I'll attatch a full stack trace. I guess it's
something to do with OC4Js connection pool handling mechanisms, even though I've
set the connection pool to none.

title: Message Queue client imq.jar available in a maven repository
body:
As discussed with Ed and Linda in my talk at Community One, much Java development is done using
Maven. A project that does not make it's libraries available via Maven is very difficult to work with and
will be actively avoided by a significant percentage of the development community.

The ehcache project is adding JMS support right now and is having to manually install the imq.jar as it
is not available in any Maven module. Please add to one of the Sun Maven repositories.

Doing this for mq 4.3 and on is ok as this is the new version that new development will be targeting
anyway.

To be very specific, I and anyone else using Open MQ needs to be able to declare a dependency like so:

<dependency>
<groupId>com.sun.messaging</groupId>
<artifactId>imq</artifactId>
<version>4.3</version>
<scope>test</scope>
</dependency>

There are currently three Sun Maven repositories I use. To add all of them to you Maven project so that
you could resolve the above you do:

<repositories>
<repository>
<id>java.net</id>
<url>[http://download.java.net/maven/1](http://download.java.net/maven/1)</url>
<layout>legacy</layout>
<releases>
<enabled>true</enabled>
<updatePolicy>daily</updatePolicy>
</releases>
<snapshots>
<enabled>false</enabled>
<updatePolicy>daily</updatePolicy>
</snapshots>
</repository>
<repository>
<id>glassfish-repository</id>
<name>Java.net Repository for Glassfish</name>
<url>[http://download.java.net/maven/glassfish](http://download.java.net/maven/glassfish)</url>
<releases>
<enabled>true</enabled>
<updatePolicy>daily</updatePolicy>
</releases>
<snapshots>
<enabled>false</enabled>
<updatePolicy>daily</updatePolicy>
</snapshots>
</repository>
<repository>
<id>java.net2</id>
<name>Java.net Maven2 Repository</name>
<url>[http://download.java.net/maven/2](http://download.java.net/maven/2)</url>
<releases>
<enabled>true</enabled>
<updatePolicy>daily</updatePolicy>
</releases>
<snapshots>
<enabled>false</enabled>
<updatePolicy>daily</updatePolicy>
</snapshots>
</repository>
</repositories>

Please, please add this to mq4.3\. It is trivial.
#### Environment
Operating System: All
Platform: All
#### Affected Versions
[current]

title: problem invoking more than 2 concurrent consumers on a queue
body:
According to:

[http://docs.sun.com/app/docs/doc/820-4917/aerbj?a=view](http://docs.sun.com/app/docs/doc/820-4917/aerbj?a=view)

"Figure 2â€“2 Complex Point-to-Point Messaging" --> a queue can be set-up to be
used by multiple consumers concurrently (each consumer with separate message
from a queue).

Simple setup with multiple standalone clients producing (a lot) of text messages
into the queue and 3 MDB's listening to the same queue shows that only 2 MDB's
are invoked by glassfish/mq at a time (concurrently).

I tried playing with maxNumActiveConsumers set to -1 and consumerFlowLimit to 1

*   same thing - glassfish/mq (as per server.log) is creating only 2 consumers at
    a time.

/mareks
#### Environment
Operating System: All
Platform: Sun
#### Affected Versions
[current]

title: NA
body:
@glassfishrobot Commented 
mareks@java.net said:
Please, close the issue. The problem was in producer's ability to feed enough
messages in a queue. Too much work was spent creating
connection->session->destination->message(s) in each producer's thread. By
creating connection globally and delegating session->destination->message(s)
creation one are able to feed queue properly and see how glassfish/mq is
creating enough mdb instances to service incoming messages in parallel.

/mareks

title: Embedded OpenMQ
body:
It would be great if the OpenMQ had the ability to run embedded in the same JVM
as another (your) application.

This would be useful for smaller applications were you do not want to have to
install OpenMQ as is only required for the life of the application. Or if you
needed to implement the HTTP tunnel and you wanted both the Servlet Container
and the OpenMQ applications to run together, this would be seriously beneficial.

Platform: All

title: Granularity of logging shoule be enhanced
body:
As an openmq / sjmq user i really miss features like class/package based logging
a lot. when you are used to this (glassfish for example does this) it is very
very usefull for debugging issues as well as turning off anoying messages that
you dont want to see.

this thread gives a brief idea on how this could e.g. be usefull. there are a
lot more.

[http://forums.sun.com/thread.jspa?messageID=10472747](http://forums.sun.com/thread.jspa?messageID=10472747)

christian DOT brennsteiner AT gmail DOT com

regards chris

title: provide option to destroy all connections for a service
body:
In cases where a broker becomes corrupted (by any reason maybe wrong usage) it
should be possible to drain a broker in a conventional cluster easilly.

AS IT IS TODAY:
when a broker becomes corrupted in a conventional cluster i as glassfish
administrator have no clue which broker serves which connections in an appserver
in a cluster. therefor i have to put the broker into quiesce mode and kill all
producers of the broker by listing them manually with

imqcmd list cxn
and
imqcmd destroy cxn

this is a very error prune process when dealing with hundreds of connections.
therefore a broker should support killing connections by e.g. type (consumer /
producer)

the following news group thread gives more details on the current situation:
[http://forums.sun.com/thread.jspa?threadID=5338245&tstart=0](http://forums.sun.com/thread.jspa?threadID=5338245&tstart=0)

email me at christian DOR brennsteiner AT gmail DOT com.

regards chris

title: Administration GUI for Messages should be provided by openmq /SJMQ
body:
A gui(or a description how to use third party apps) for editing / deleting /
listing messages should be provided by openmq.

nowadays there is no defacto standard tool provided by sun for introspecting
queues of a standalone JMQ server. there are some workrounds available as using
third party apps or similar.

this issue should adress to a defacto standard gui for introspecting messages.
features include

showing payloads

title: AMQP
body:
Interoperability is one of the things that is most needed in current MOMs on the
market. A business aliance now tries to solve this by implemented a standard
protocol for MOMs: AMQP (see amqp.org). As openess should be one of the topmost
targest of a product called "OPEN MQ", as a user of this product I demand for
first class support of AMQP in OpenMQ. Moreover, I appeal that Sun Microsystems
takes a seat in amqp.org's board to control the further development of this
standard. It is not acceptable that in near future there will be a lot of
interoperable products and Sun Microsystem, as the inventor of the de-facto MOM
API "JMS", is not playing any role in this.

title: imqbrokerd will not start if using PostgreSQL 8.2/8.3
body:
From this forum thread:
[http://forums.sun.com/thread.jspa?messageID=10604416&#10604416](http://forums.sun.com/thread.jspa?messageID=10604416&#10604416)

I did not see any existing issues with a search for 'postgresql' so assumed one
had not yet been opened.

Using PostgreSQL 8.3.6\. "imqdbmgr create tbl" can be used successfully to
initialize the database for an HA broker configuration. However, imqbrokerd
fails with this exception:

06/Mar/2009:13:56:57 EST] ERROR [B3198]: Error initializing cluster manager:
com.sun.messaging.jmq.jmsserver.util.BrokerException: [B4221]: Failed to load
all HA cluster information from store
at
com.sun.messaging.jmq.jmsserver.persist.jdbc.BrokerDAOImpl.getAllBrokerInfos(BrokerDAOImpl.java:1077)
at
com.sun.messaging.jmq.jmsserver.persist.jdbc.JDBCStore.getAllBrokerInfos(JDBCStore.java:2764)
at com.sun.messaging.jmq.jmsserver.persist.Store.getAllBrokerInfos(Store.java:1212)
at
com.sun.messaging.jmq.jmsserver.cluster.ha.HAClusterManagerImpl$HAMap.<init>(HAClusterManagerImpl.java:1453)
at
com.sun.messaging.jmq.jmsserver.cluster.ha.HAClusterManagerImpl.getAllBrokers(HAClusterManagerImpl.java:145)
at
com.sun.messaging.jmq.jmsserver.cluster.ClusterManagerImpl.initialize(ClusterManagerImpl.java:878)
at
com.sun.messaging.jmq.jmsserver.cluster.ha.HAClusterManagerImpl.initialize(HAClusterManagerImpl.java:188)
at com.sun.messaging.jmq.jmsserver.Globals.initClusterManager(Globals.java:887)
at com.sun.messaging.jmq.jmsserver.Broker._start(Broker.java:790)
at com.sun.messaging.jmq.jmsserver.Broker.start(Broker.java:417)
at com.sun.messaging.jmq.jmsserver.Broker.start(Broker.java:388)
at com.sun.messaging.jmq.jmsserver.Broker.main(Broker.java:1945)
Caused by: java.sql.SQLException: [SELECT bTbl.ID, URL, VERSION, STATE,
TAKEOVER_BROKER, HEARTBEAT_TS, sTbl.ID STORE_SESSION_ID FROM MQBKR41Cwildfire
bTbl LEFT JOIN MQSES41Cwildfire sTbl ON bTbl.ID = sTbl.BROKER_ID AND
sTbl.IS_CURRENT = 1]: ERROR: syntax error at or near "STORE_SESSION_ID"
at
com.sun.messaging.jmq.jmsserver.persist.jdbc.DBManager.wrapSQLException(DBManager.java:863)
at
com.sun.messaging.jmq.jmsserver.persist.jdbc.BrokerDAOImpl.getAllBrokerInfos(BrokerDAOImpl.java:1072)
... 11 more

The reason is that "AS" is being omitted in the select clause alias "sTbl.ID
STORE_SESSION_ID".

As noted in linked forum post there is a workaround via source code modification
but wanted to ensure it was captured in the issue tracker.
#### Environment
Operating System: Linux
Platform: All
#### Affected Versions
[current]

title: Non UTF-8-encoded properties and C-API
body:
Using the C-API and the MQSetStringProperty-function to set a non (valid) UTF-8-
encoded value (or key) and then send (produce) the message works fine as well
as read (consume) the message and then use the MQGetStringProperty-function.
When a Java-client tries to consume the message, it gets a
sun.messaging.jms.JMSException (from java.io.UTFDataFormatException)

...
MQMessageHandle handle;
...
const char * const key = "key";
const char * const value = "Ã...Ã„Ã-"; // a non valid UTF-8-encoded byte-array
const MQStatus status = MQSetStringProperty( handle, key, value );
#### Environment

Platform: Sun

title: NA
body:
@glassfishrobot Commented 
amyk@java.net said:
In C-API Developer Guide, the key/value arguments of MQSetStringProperty
function are specified as ConstMQString type which is defined as a constant
MQString - a null terminated UTF-8 encoded character string. The function
itself does not detect if the string passed in is UTF-8 encoded

title: NA
NA
body:
@glassfishrobot Commented 
This issue was imported from java.net JIRA MQ-20

title: UTF-8-enhancements in C-API
body:
Since ANSI C or ANCI C++ don't (yet) have any standard support to encode/decode
UTF-8 and the C-API (should) only accept UTF-encoded strings some helf-
functionality would be desirable

One solution would be that the API always accepted 8-bit characters for input
and then did encoding internally and when accessing strings the API could
decode the string into 8-bit-characters (and report error if the UTF-8-encoded
value doesn't fit into a 8-bit-character string)

Another solution would be to double up the interfaces/functions and have
functions like MQSetStringProperty along with MQSetUTF8Property or perhaps
MQSetLatinProperty with MQSetUnicodeProperty (where the second one demanded a
UTF-8-encoded string) and MQGetDestinationNameAsString with
MQGetDestinationNameAsUTF or something etc.

Yet another solution, and the most likely, would be to provide som standalone-
help-functionality like MQEncodeWideString and MQEncodeNarrowString along with
MQDecodeToWide and MQDecodeToNarrow (where the last version somehow must report
an error if a decoded value doesn't fit into a (narrowed) 8-bit-value)
#### Environment
Operating System: Solaris
Platform: Sun
#### Affected Versions
[current]

title: Message redelivery limit and retry interval
body:
Currently if a message fails in a transacted environment, for example when a
client throws an exception while processing a message, the OpenMQ broker will
attempt to redeliver the message indefinitely, with no delay.
It would be useful to be able to define a maximum number of redelivery attempts,
and an interval between each delivery attempt.

The most specific use case to illustrate this:
A client is in some state where the message will always fail, and thus always be
resent by the broker. Manual intervention is the only solution to stop this cycle.
#### Environment
Operating System: All
Platform: All
#### Affected Versions
[4.1, 4.2, 4.3, 4.4, 4.4u1, 4.4u2, 4.5, 4.5.1, 4.5.2]

body:
This is related to Glassfish issue
[https://glassfish.dev.java.net/issues/show_bug.cgi?id=4322](https://glassfish.dev.java.net/issues/show_bug.cgi?id=4322)

Both in GF v2 and v3 port unification is supported for HTTP, HTTPS (and possibly
IIOP). A ProtocolFinder detects which protocol connects on a given TCP port and
then delegates handling to a ProtocolHandler. See
[http://weblogs.java.net/blog/jfarcand/archive/2006/11/one_port_to_rul.html](http://weblogs.java.net/blog/jfarcand/archive/2006/11/one_port_to_rul.html)

OpenMQ should be able to participate in port unification. This would support
this use case related to applicaton client containers (ACC):
1\. HTTP to download via Java Webstart
2\. IIOP to get JNDI admin objects from server
3\. OpenMQ to send/receive messages to/from server

The JavaWS client could run on a remote site and only one port has to opened in
the firewall instead of 3.
#### Environment
Operating System: All
Platform: All
#### Affected Versions
[current]

title: Memory leak when creating TemporaryTopic.
body:
I am using TemporaryTopic in my app. The implementation for this
(TemporaryTopicImpl) extends TemporaryDestination, which extends Destination,
which extends AdministeredObject, the constructor for which looks for
configuration data from properties files. It is looking for
Destination_defaults.properties, Destination_types.properties, and
Destination_labels.properties, but these are not included in the source tree or
any of the jars. Because these files cannot be found, the AdministeredObject
constructor calls setDefaultConfiguration(). An implementation for this is
found in Destination. However I see a memory leak in this method. It creates
three new Properties objects, and puts some String objects into those. When
profiling the app in NetBeans, I find that these Properties objects and the
Strings inside them are never garbage collected. My app is only holding the
TemporaryTopic object in a local variable so I'm pretty sure it's not a coding
error on my part (although I'd be happy to be proved wrong on this). Presumably
a reference to the TemporaryTopic is being held somewhere else, otherwise I'd
expect garbage collection to take care of things. Because I call the method
that uses TemporaryTopic on a regular basis, the memory leak becomes significant
after a few hours.
#### Environment
Operating System: All
Platform: Macintosh
#### Affected Versions
[current]

title: NA
body:
@glassfishrobot Commented 
sivewrig@java.net said:
Hi jeppehans,
Please can you provide some more info on your usage of temp dests.
Temporary destinations are held by the connection that created them. They
should be automatically cleaned up when the connection closes. Are you
creating lots of temp destinations on the same connection?
If so, are you calling calling TempDestination.delete()?
Thanks,
Gordon

title: NA
body:
@glassfishrobot Commented 
sivewrig@java.net said:
We found a memory leak in the client. TemporaryDestinations belonging to a
connection are held in a collection. TemporaryDestination instances were not
being removed from this collection when TemporaryDestination.delete() was
called.

This has now been fixed. The corresponding CR for this issue is:
6892512 Memory Leak: Temporary Destinations are not removed from connection
when tempDest.delete() is called

Thanks for reporting this.

title: High load when new brokers enter cluster
body:
We have a cluster with 4 nodes, two per colo with a 155ms latency between colos. When a new broker
enters the cluster (after a restart or maintenance outage), the master broker has a large load spike, which
slows things down enough that some jms messages are dropped and sometimes prevents the new broker
from attaching to the cluster.

We are using version 4.4 build 9.
#### Environment
Operating System: Linux
Platform: Other
#### Affected Versions
[current]

body:
@glassfishrobot Commented 
mondokat@java.net said:
Although I was unable to reproduce this in testing, it is still definitely an issue in our production
environment. The only noticeable difference in the two environments is message content/size.

We are still using 4 cluster nodes. I am wondering if it would be wise to utilize a master broker that no
clients connect to directly, in order to alleviate some load.

Any other suggestions?

title: NA
NA
body:
@glassfishrobot Commented 
amyk@java.net said:
When a broker startup, it needs to sync up with the master broker first, yes
the master broker's load will be up, and if there are messages already waiting
for remote consumers, as soon as the sync is done, the messages will be
flowing to the remote broker. If you have producers on master broker that have
remote consumers or consumers on the master broker that consume messages
remotely, it will be helpful to miminize master broker's JMS service.

title: Broker Isolation
body:
We have a cluster with 4 nodes, two per colo, 155ms latency between colos. We are using 4.4 build 9\.

Occasionally, after a broker restart, the broker seems to be unable to rejoin the cluster. The destinations
all appear, and the query bkr command shows the broker as active, but not all consumers/producers
appear. Some messages will only work in one direction (aproducer on the broker can send messages out,
but can't consume messages on the same destination). The isolation is assymetrical (some brokers report
the isolated broker as active and some not).

So far, the only fix we have found for this is to shut down all brokers, remove their fs370 directory, and
restart them.
#### Environment
Operating System: Linux
Platform: Other
#### Affected Versions
[current]

title: Msgs 'Remote' can become higher than 'Count'  in 'imqcmd list dst'
body:
We have a cluster of 4 brokers, two per colo, 155ms latency per colo. We are using 4.4 build 9\.

Occasionally we observe that the numbers presented in the "list dst" command don't seem to match up.
For example, 3 brokers will say under the Msgs section, count=0, remote=0, unack=0, but a fourth will
say count=0, remote=277, unack=0\. This 277 will not change for weeks at a time. The only way to "reset"
it seems to be to stop it and remove its fs370 directory.

We don't use persistent messages, so it is unclear why this happens.
#### Environment
Operating System: Linux
Platform: Other
#### Affected Versions
[current]

title: NA
body:
* **Issue Imported From:** https://github.com/javaee/openmq/issues/30
* **Original Issue Raised By:**@glassfishrobot
* **Original Issue  Assigned To:** Unassigned
* **Original Issue  Closed By:**@glassfishrobot

title: NA
body:
@glassfishrobot Commented 
Reported by mondokat@java.net

title: NA
body:
@glassfishrobot Commented 
mondokat@java.net said:
I managed to duplicate this error in a test environment. I had two brokers on
each side of a 166ms latency link, and a producer/consumer pair on each side as
well. I used no-ack mode to send 750msgs/sec to a topic from each producer and
had each consumer subscribe to the topic. Broker 1 was the master for this
cluster. After a short while, the producer connected to the master gave the
following error:

[2009-09-03 18:14:23,153] ERROR [main]
com.adconion.jms.testclient.SimpleProducerApp: connect or send failed
org.springframework.jms.ResourceAllocationException: [C4096]: Destination is
full and is rejecting new messages: amg.test.topic user=guest,
broker=broker1.test.com:7676(51398); nested exception is
com.sun.messaging.jms.ResourceAllocationException: [C4096]: Destination is full
and is rejecting new messages: amg.test.topic user=guest,
broker=broker1.test.com:7676(51398)

This sounded odd to me, because the topic had flow control enabled. After this,
using the imqcmd list dst command gave the following output:

------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Name Type State Producers Consumers
Msgs
Total Wildcard Total Wildcard Count
Remote UnAck Avg Size
------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
amg.test.queue Queue RUNNING 0 - 0 - 0
0 0 0.0
amg.test.topic Topic RUNNING 0 0 1 0 0
4444 0 0.0
mq.sys.dmq Queue RUNNING 0 - 0 - 0
0 0 0.0

That's maybe hard to read, but it shows "remote" at 4444\. On the other broker
it shows all zeroes. Consumers will consume no more messages.

I am assuming that the error message actually means that a broker has reached
it's maximum total messages (system wide and not for a specific destination).

I also did this using 4.4 build 15 this time.

title: NA
body:
@glassfishrobot Commented 
amyk@java.net said:
Could you please provide the broker exception in the broker log corresponding to
the client
ResourceAllocationException ?

What was the output 'imqcmd query bkr' ?
What was the ouptut 'imqcmd query dst' on amg.test.topic ?

What do you mean by "used no-ack mode to send .. to a topic from each producer
and had each consumer subscribe to the topic" ? Do you use NO_ACKNOWLEDGE
mode for the 2 subscribers ? if not, what are the ack mode for the subscribers
? or/and any producer or consumer using transactions ?

You were sending NON_PERSISTENT messages, correct ? Did you use message
non-zero timeToLive on sending messages ?

What were the configurations for your client connection factories ? Both broker
configuration properties ?

If you stop the producers, then restart (without -reset store option and without
removing fs370) the broker that showed 4444 remote count in 'imqcmd list dst',
run 'imqcmd list dst' again, does the remote count go back to 0 ?

com.sun.messaging.jmq.jmsserver.util.BrokerException: [B4024]: The Maximum
Number of messages currently in the system [ 5000 ] has been exceeded,
rejecting message 603397-207.171.14.131(fd:78:c1:5e:35:45)-50371-1252001663144

I will attach the output of those commands so maybe it will be easier to read...

In my test, I am using NO_ACKNOWLEDGE mode for all producers and subscribers.
We are using NON-PERSISTENT messages with no TTL.

The consumer config was like this:

<bean id="messageLoggingListenerContainer"
class="org.springframework.jms.listener.DefaultMessageListenerContainer">
<property name="connectionFactory" ref="singleJmsConnectionFactory" />
<property name="destinationName" value="amg.test.topic" />
<property name="messageListener" ref="loggingMessageListener" />
<property name="concurrentConsumers" value="1" />
<property name="maxConcurrentConsumers" value="1" />
<property name="autoStartup" value="false" />
<property name="sessionAcknowledgeMode" value="32768" />
<property name="cacheLevelName" value="CACHE_CONSUMER" />
</bean>

The producer's config is like this:

<bean id="producerJmsTemplate"
class="org.springframework.jms.core.JmsTemplate">
<!-- need rawJmsConnectionFactory for NO_ACKNOWLEDGE mode. -->
<property name="connectionFactory" ref="singleJmsConnectionFactory" />
<property name="explicitQosEnabled" value="true" />
<property name="deliveryPersistent" value="false" />
<property name="sessionAcknowledgeMode" value="32768" />
</bean>

I restarted the master broker, and the "remote" messages went away, but as soon
as I did it, I realized I should have had some producers/consumers running to
better simulate when we tried this in our production environment. In
production, the messages wouldn't go away.

D'oh, i restarted before querying the destination for you. I'll post query bkr
output though, and the broker configs momentarily.

title: NA
body:
@glassfishrobot Commented 
amyk@java.net said:
1\. The following broker exception is expected when number of messages in the
broker exceeds imq.system.max_count (which you have set to 5000) regardless
limitBehavior of the destination. The Administration Guide is not clear on
that and there is already a doc bug 6874871 filed to clarify this.

[B4024]: The Maximum Number of messages currently in the system [ 5000 ]
has been exceeded

2\. It appears that your producer SimpleProducerApp to amg.test.topic was either
producing PERSISTENT messages or has connection factory property imqAckOnProduce
set to true. Otherwise it would not wait for reply from broker to get that
client exception [C4096]

3\. Since the 'Remote' count went back to 0, after you stopped the producers and
restarted broker without reset store, this is not a "persistent store
corruption" issue.

4\. The 'imqcmd list dst' showed Msgs 'Count' 0 but 'Remote' 4444, this is a
bug for 'Remote' should not exceed 'Count'. Therefore I'v changed this issue's
Summary line accordingly

title: NA

I have not been able to reproduce #4 using simple publisher/subscriber with
different placement of a latency ~140ms network either between the 2 brokers or
between consumer to its local broker and with or without imq.system.max_count
set to trigger [B4024]. It would be helpful if you have a JMS test case without
using Spring that reproduces #4.

title: NA
body:

Please note that #4 is only a count tracking bug on 'Remote' for 'imqcmd list
dst'. It's not a remote message processing issue. One should always rely on
'Count' in 'imqcmd list dst'.

I know persistent messages is turned off, we are using sessionAcknowledgeMode set to 32768 for
producers. Shouldn't be any acks, correct?

I was able to reproduce the funny numbers in list dst again today with build 9, but am having troubles
with build 15 and 16, it may be fixed.

With build 9, I had 4 brokers, two on each side of a 155ms latency link. I had both a consumer and a
producer producing 500 msgs/sec attached to each broker. Fairly quickly, 3 of the brokers had a
"count" that was stuck (consumers couldn't consume any more, but there were still messages listed
under count) and one broker had a "remote" that was stuck.

The numbers didn't add up, either. 300 on one broker, 80 on another, 110 on the third, all with zero
"remote". The last had 87 "remote" but count=0\.

Again, I had trouble reproducing this on newer builds.

title: NA

@glassfishrobot Commented

Hm, I tried build 16 with the same config as prior and it looks like it suffered poorer performance and it
didn't keep up with the producers and the topic eventually hit the configured 500 message maximum I
had, and when that happened, the numbers skewed in a manner similar to build 9\.

It may have something to do with the fact that I left the consumers and producers on, trying to connect,
even though the broker was off. This way, when it comes on, it has clients connecting before it ever has a
chance to sync up with the master.

It also seems to make a difference how many brokers I have. 3 or less exhibits the problem much less. The
issue really shows itself with 4 brokers.

title: need user-friendly message when arithmetic exc. occurs in selector
body:
When I specify a selector that can lead to an arithmetic condition (e.g. "1/0"),
a JMSException is thrown but from the message it is difficult to understand what
happened:

com.sun.messaging.jms.JMSException: [ADD_CONSUMER_REPLY(15)] [C4036]: A broker
error occurred. :[500] [B4117]: Unexpected Broker Exception: [Unexpected Error
processing message]

This type of issue with a selector leads to an internal error in the broker,
which causes the "[B4117]: Unexpected Broker Exception" message to be logged by
both the broker and the client. The broker's log will also include a
ArithmeticException in the stacktrace, but at the client side the root cause is
not logged.

In the broker's log.txt:
ERROR [B3100]: Unexpected Broker Internal Error : [Uncaught Exception]:
com.sun.messaging.jmq.jmsserver.util.BrokerException?: [B4117]: Unexpected
Broker Exception: [Unexpected Error processing message]

at
com.sun.messaging.jmq.jmsserver.data.PacketRouter?.handleMessage(PacketRouter?.java:198)
at
com.sun.messaging.jmq.jmsserver.service.imq.IMQIPConnection.readData(IMQIPConnection.java:1493)
at
com.sun.messaging.jmq.jmsserver.service.imq.IMQIPConnection.process(IMQIPConnection.java:663)
at
com.sun.messaging.jmq.jmsserver.service.imq.OperationRunnable?.process(OperationRunnable?.java:170)
at
com.sun.messaging.jmq.jmsserver.util.pool.BasicRunnable?.run(BasicRunnable?.java:493)
at java.lang.Thread.run(Thread.java:595) Caused by:
java.lang.ArithmeticException: / by zero at
com.sun.messaging.jmq.util.selector.Selector.doNumericOperation(Selector.java:1795)
at com.sun.messaging.jmq.util.selector.Selector.match(Selector.java:1420)

(This is on GFv2 so the line numbers might not match anymore.)

With the patch that I'm going to attach, this case will be treated as a syntax
error, and the messages will change as follows:

Client application log:

messageSelector 'LongName == 300 + 150 / 0'
com.sun.messaging.jms.InvalidSelectorException: [C4022]: Selector invalid:
LongName == 300 + 150 / 0\. user=guest, broker=NS07-0471:7676(55831)
at
com.sun.messaging.jmq.jmsclient.ProtocolHandler.addInterest(ProtocolHandler.java:2213)

Broker log:

WARNING [B2106]: Creation of consumer from connection
guest@10.13.20.15:55867 on the auto-created destination Queue failed:
com.sun.messaging.jmq.jmsserver.util.BrokerException: [B2016]: Unable to parse
selector LongName == 300 + 150 / 0

I have signed the SCA. Would you incorporate this patch in openmq?
#### Environment
Operating System: All
Platform: All
#### Affected Versions
[current]

title: fix for int-> long overflows
body:
In April I found and fixed an issue in GlassFish's JTA where the
multiplication of two integers and a subsequent cast to a long led to
IllegalArgumentException because the value had become negative.

[https://glassfish.dev.java.net/issues/show_bug.cgi?id=7979](https://glassfish.dev.java.net/issues/show_bug.cgi?id=7979)

For example:
timer.schedule(this,timeout * 1000);

schedule() takes a long, but if 'timeout' is bigger than MAX_INT/1000,
the value will become negative.

Searching through the V3 source code I found many similar cases. I have fixed
them all in GlassFish, and will attach diffs to fix them in MQ code.

Some of the 'timeout' variables might never reach a big enough value, or
code might not be used any more, but as it's better safe than sorry I've
addressed them in the attached diff (added 'L' to integer 1000).
#### Environment
Operating System: All
Platform: All
#### Affected Versions
[current]

title: OpenMQ installer: "Invalid SwiXML Descriptor" error when ran under ja locale
body:
When ran 4.4 U1 Open MQ installer under Japanese locale, click "Next" in the
first welcome dialog, error dialog pops up saying something like;

Internal error occured. Please contact system administrator. Detailed
information are shown below. For additional information please refer to log
file. To terminate, click OK.
Invalid SwiXML Descriptor.

Following is console output.

[root@localhost openmq4_4-installer]# ./installer
SwixML 1.5 (#144)
org.jdom.input.JDOMParsesrException: Error on line 353: An invalid XML character
(Unicode 0x0) was found in the element content of the document.
WARNING: Couldn't process navigation event of command=AC_NEXT [command=AC_NEXT
error=Invalid SwiXML Descriptor. ]

Note that above messages may not be actual English as are translated back from
Japanese output.

Users cannot complete install.
Seems like it is also the case in other locales. I confirmed it also in zh_CN at
least. When ran under C locale, the problem doesn't exist.
Tested Build3-d-4.4u1 openmq4_4-installer-Linux_X86.zip
#### Environment
Operating System: Linux
Platform: PC
#### Affected Versions
[current]

title: Make IMQ connection factory java bean compliant
body:
[http://hermesjms.com](http://hermesjms.com) relies upon connection factory beans to be Java bean
compliant with getters and setters for all properties for users not using JNDI.
Most JMS providers work this way with the notable exception of IMQ. Could I
have the methods included in a future version? Regards, Colin.

title: Messages not getting persisted on Topic using Txn. Session
body:
I noticed this problem when using the version of Sun MQ which ships with GES
2.13\. ALthough we are using a Sun supported version of Glassfish and Sun
Message Queue, I believe that the open source version of MQ is the same and so
I am posting this issue here. I have also opened a Sun ticket for this - ticket
71896734

Setup:
You have an existing durable subscription to a topic destination. ClientId = X,
SubscriptionName = S. The consumer should be inactive. The current number
of messages on the destination = 0.

Steps:
Open a new connection, a new transacted session, and a new producer on the same
destination D, using the same clientId X.
It is important that you use the same clientId "X" as the inactive consumer.
Publish one message. Commit the session
Close the producer, session and connection.
At this time, you would have expected that the message would have got persisted
on the destination for the inactive client "X".

Observation:
a) The number of messages on the destination remain at 0.
b) The JMS server side log contains a error message:

Reference already gone for <msg id of published message>

c) If you use a non-transacted session, then the message does get persisted to
the topic.

Attachments:
1) Sample java class that will create a transacted session and produce a
message. All values such as JNDI settings, etc are hard coded in the java file.
The code sets the connection client id to be the value "undefined"
2) Output of client when running in debug mode (imq.debug.all)

Pre-Requisite Conditions Before Running Java Test Code:
You must somehow create a durable consumer with clientId "undefined" on the
destination before run the java class.

Software Versions:
This was tested using JDK 1.5 and 1.6 on the client side. We are using the
follwing Sun MQ version:

Sun Java(tm) System Message Queue 4.3
Sun Microsystems, Inc.
Version: 4.3 (Build 7-g)
Compile: Fri Nov 7 18:14:54 PST 2008

with JDK 1.6.0_07\.

This version of MQ is the version that ships with Glassfish Enterprise Server
2.13.
#### Environment
Operating System: All
Platform: All
#### Affected Versions
[current]

in messages with arguments.

title: Prematurely reached system message limit.
body:
I am testing out 4.4u1 build 5\. I have 2 brokers with a 160ms latency between them. I have a consumer
and producer attached to a topic on each broker, and each producer is producing 500 messages per
second with persistence turned off and using noack mode. This should be a max of 1000 messages/sec
on the topic.

The topic was set up with this config:

imqcmd update dst -t t -n amg.test.topic -o useDMQ=false -o limitBehavior=REMOVE_OLDEST -o
maxNumMsgs=500

With this running, within seconds I see these error messages:

[13/Nov/2009:17:55:53 GMT] Ref null for 97181-207.171.14.34(ad:5d:6c:3d:ae:84)34390
1258134945288
[13/Nov/2009:17:55:53 GMT] Ref null for 97321-207.171.14.34(ad:5d:6c:3d:ae:84)34390
1258134945568
[13/Nov/2009:17:55:53 GMT] Ref null for 97365-207.171.14.34(ad:5d:6c:3d:ae:84)34390
1258134945656

Then I see this:

[13/Nov/2009:18:01:11 GMT] WARNING [B2011]: Storing of JMS message from
IMQConn[AUTHENTICATED,guest@10.61.3.64:37557,null] failed:
com.sun.messaging.jmq.jmsserver.util.BrokerException: [B4024]: The Maximum Number of messages
currently in the system [ 5000 ] has been exceeded, rejecting message 114921-
10.61.3.64(9a:33:b0:1d:85:24)-37557-1258135271358
[13/Nov/2009:18:01:11 GMT] [B1066]: Closing: guest@10.61.3.64:37557->jms:43488 because
"[B0059]: Client closed the connection". Count: service=0 broker=3

And one of my producers disconnects. I can't see anywhere that the message count has reached 5k
when i use the list dst command, and the "maxNumMsgs=500" config should have limited that topic to
500 messages anyway, preventing this from happening. Worst case scenario, the broker should be
dropping older messages because of the "REMOVE_OLDEST".
#### Environment
Operating System: Linux
Platform: PC
#### Affected Versions
[current]

body:
@glassfishrobot Commented 
amyk@java.net said:
> [13/Nov/2009:17:55:53 GMT] Ref null for
97181-207.171.14.34(ad:5d:6c:3d:ae:84)-34390-1258134945288

This supposed to be logged at debug level. It means on removing the message the
message has already been removed from the destionation. The log message has
been changed to be more self-explanatory and to be logged at debug level in
4.4u1 on Sep 22 2009 which happened before 4.4u1 build3 (in Oct 2009). So it
appears that you were using a build before 4.4u1 build3\. Please upgrade to the
latest 4.4u1 build for all your brokers and run your test again. Thanks.

> [13/Nov/2009:18:01:11 GMT] WARNING [B2011]: Storing of JMS message .. failed:
> com.sun.messaging.jmq.jmsserver.util.BrokerException: [B4024]: The Maximum
Number of messages currently in the system [ 5000 ] has been exceeded,
rejecting message

You must have broker property imq.system.max_count=5000 set for this warning to
show up in broker log. Regarding the "rejecting message", this will happen
when system-wide limit reached regardless your setting of limitBehavior per
destination.

I assure you this was done on 4.4u1_b5(rc3). I downloaded it from here:

[http://download.java.net/mq/open-mq/4.4u1/b5-rc3/openmq4_4-binary-Linux_X86.zip](http://download.java.net/mq/open-mq/4.4u1/b5-rc3/openmq4_4-binary-Linux_X86.zip)

To be safe, I downloaded it again and did an md5sum against the file i downloaded before and got the
same thing.

> You must have broker property imq.system.max_count=5000 set for this warning to
> show up in broker log. Regarding the "rejecting message", this will happen
> when system-wide limit reached regardless your setting of limitBehavior per
> destination.

Yes, I do have this set. However, I am only sending messages on a single topic, with max messages on
that topic set to 500\. How can I reach the 5k limit when my only destination has a max of 500?

Also, if you look at the list dst output above, you can see that the "remote" count on app15.muc's
broker says "4095". These messages don't appear to actually exist anywhere (they aren't on etl3.lax's
broker, so where are they?). Also, how can "remote" on the destination be that high when "max" is set
to 500? This makes no sense to me.

On top of all that, because Issue 30's fix should be in this build, the remote count shouldn't be greater
than the "count" anyway.

@glassfishrobot Commented 
amyk@java.net said:
This is an existing issue with broker total message count when multiple
publishers producing NON_PERSISTENT messages concurrently with a subscriber
consuming messages with NO_ACK mode. This issue can be reproduced on a single
broker as well. I'v filed This is an existing issue with broker total message count when multiple
publishers producing NON_PERSISTENT messages concurrently with a subscriber
consuming messages with NO_ACK mode. This issue can be reproduced on a single
broker as well. I'v filed bug 6903267\. To workaround the "rejecting message"
warning on system limit, set imq.system.max_count to unlimited (-1, default)
since all your destinations have destination limit set.. To workaround the "rejecting message"
warning on system limit, set imq.system.max_count to unlimited (-1, default)
since all your destinations have destination limit set.

title: NA
body:
@glassfishrobot Commented 
mondokat@java.net said:
So this is purely a metric display/counting error? Just making sure when I see the "Total Message Bytes in
System" counter constantly going up that it won't eat all available memory if I turn the max system
messages limitation off.

title: NA
body:
@glassfishrobot Commented 
amyk@java.net said:
Yes, Yes, bug 6903267 is a total message counting issue affecting "Current Number of
Messages in System" and "Current Total Message Bytes in System" of 'imqcmd query
bkr'.
is a total message counting issue affecting "Current Number of
Messages in System" and "Current Total Message Bytes in System" of 'imqcmd query

title: NA
body:
@glassfishrobot Commented 
mondokat@java.net said:
So I removed the system message limit (set it to -1, infinity). I have 2 brokers in my setup, running
4.4u1b5, a producer and consumer on each broker and am generating approximately 500 msgs/sec
per producer (total 1000 per sec on a test topic), 160ms latency between brokers.

I let it run for ~1 hour and noticed the heap was slowly increasing in utilization via the jconsole. So I let
it run till it ran out of heap space and saw this error message:

Exception in thread "RMI TCP Connection(idle)" java.lang.OutOfMemoryError: Java heap space
Exception in thread "RMI TCP Connection(idle)" java.lang.OutOfMemoryError: Java heap space
Exception in thread "RMI TCP Connection(idle)" java.lang.OutOfMemoryError: Java heap space
Exception in thread "RMI TCP Connection(idle)" java.lang.OutOfMemoryError: Java heap space
Exception in thread "RMI TCP Connection(idle)" java.lang.OutOfMemoryError: Java heap space
Exception in thread "RMI TCP Connection(idle)" Exception in thread "RMI TCP Connection(idle)"
java.lang.OutOfMemoryError: Java heap space
java.lang.OutOfMemoryError: Java heap space

Java is still running, it shows up in a process list, but the broker never responds. This is happening on
the master broker. The other broker is still up and responding, but it thinks the master is still up. All
connections to the master just time out and more entries like the above appear in the log.

So, I think either the system message counter problem DOES use up some amount of memory, or else I
am now hitting a different memory leak and removing the system message max has allowed me to see
it now.

title: NA
body:
@glassfishrobot Commented 
amyk@java.net said:
1\. For regular Topic subscriber, the broker will push messages as fast as
possible to the consumer local broker. This can cause build up of packets
waiting to be processed in cluster dispatcher if the consumer and its local
broker can't consume/process the messages fast enough when imq.system.max_count
is unlimited. This build up can be further exacerbated by JVM GC activities
when destination limitBehavior=REMOVE_OLDEST.

2\. There is an existing 1\. For regular Topic subscriber, the broker will push messages as fast as
possible to the consumer local broker. This can cause build up of packets
waiting to be processed in cluster dispatcher if the consumer and its local
broker can't consume/process the messages fast enough when imq.system.max_count
is unlimited. This build up can be further exacerbated by JVM GC activities
when destination limitBehavior=REMOVE_OLDEST.

2\. There is an existing bug 6906093 in broker that when marking a dead remote
message (e.g. removed due to destination limit), remote broker is not notified
if the destination useDMQ=false. This causes delivered messages that marked
dead by consumer local broker not to be cleared.

Both #1 and #2 will cause broker memory growth for your test environment. #1
explains the high GPacket and GPacketCallbackEvent count in the histo file you
attached, and both #1 and #2 contribute the high BrokerConsumers$ackEntry count.

The workaround for #1 and #2 is to use limitBehavior=FLOW_CONTROL or have
application thruttle the message producing rate to the brokers. in broker that when marking a dead remote
message (e.g. removed due to destination limit), remote broker is not notified
if the destination useDMQ=false. This causes delivered messages that marked
dead by consumer local broker not to be cleared.

Both #1 and #2 will cause broker memory growth for your test environment. #1
explains the high GPacket and GPacketCallbackEvent count in the histo file you
attached, and both #1 and #2 contribute the high BrokerConsumers$ackEntry count.

The workaround for #1 and #2 is to use limitBehavior=FLOW_CONTROL or have
application thruttle the message producing rate to the brokers.

body:
This patch will find Java installation in FreeBSD default locations. Applying it
will let openmq to run on freebsd7 out of box.

— src/solaris/etc/imqinit.bak 2009-12-05 23:16:02.000000000 +0100
+++ src/solaris/etc/imqinit.sh 2009-12-07 19:50:34.000000000 +0100
@@ -149,7 +149,16 @@
/usr \
"
;;
-
+ FreeBSD)
+ _j2se_locations="\
+/usr/local/openjdk6 \
+/usr/local/diablo-jdk1.6.0 \
+/usr/local/diablo-jre1.6.0 \
+/usr/local/jdk1.5.0 \
+/usr/local/diablo-jdk1.5.0 \
+/usr/local/diablo-jre1.5.0 \
+"
+ ;;
*)
_j2se_locations="\
/usr/jdk/entsys-j2se \

title: Fix race condition in broker restart/shutdown script
body:
During broker shutdown broker shutdown script must wait for java process to exit
before exiting. Not doing it will make service restart fails because startup
script will attempt to start second broker while first is still exiting.

also there might be timing issue in shutdown because shutdown can kill -9 java
process while it is not necessary because it is still exiting and busy cleaning
queue files.
#### Environment
Operating System: FreeBSD
Platform: All
#### Affected Versions
[4.4u1]

title: Broker may restart itself under certain conditions
body:
We have a 4 broker standard cluster with 2 brokers each in 2 different colos with a 160ms latency link
between them, for a total of 4 brokers. One of the brokers has mysteriously restarted itself on 12-19-
2009 at around 9:04GMT. This seems to have confused the master broker in such a way that it was not
marking messages on two of the destinations as read, which caused the destinations to fill to their max
defined message limit. The interesting tidbits are as follows.

First, on jms2.lax:

Dec 19, 2009 9:04:02 AM
INFO: Stop STOMP server
Dec 19, 2009 9:04:03 AM
INFO: Notified selection key sun.nio.ch.SelectionKeyImpl@1d2c5431 locally closed
Dec 19, 2009 9:04:03 AM
INFO: STOMP server has been stopped.
[19/Dec/2009:09:04:03 GMT] [B1072]: Closed cluster connection to broker
mq://207.171.14.53:7676/?
instName=jms1.lax.adconion.com&brokerSessionUID=3903817679257585664
[19/Dec/2009:09:04:03 GMT] [B1047]: Shutting down broker...
[19/Dec/2009:09:04:03 GMT] WARNING [B2110]: Send GOODBYE to mq://10.61.3.70:7676/?
instName=jms1.muc.adconion.com&brokerSessionUID=6095381847935125760
failed:java.io.IOException: Cluster unicast unreachable address
[19/Dec/2009:09:04:03 GMT] WARNING [B2110]: Send GOODBYE to mq://10.61.3.71:7676/?
instName=jms2.muc.adconion.com&brokerSessionUID=63681311005714283
52 failed:

So at 09:04, jms2 seems to have had some sort of stomp connection, stomp stopped, then the entire
broker restarted itself, sending goodbyes to the other brokers.

The master broker saw this:

[19/Dec/2009:09:04:03 GMT] [B1072]: Closed cluster connection to broker
mq://207.171.14.54:7676/?
instName=jms2.lax.adconion.com&brokerSessionUID=7346819594573956352
[19/Dec/2009:09:04:03 GMT] ERROR Unable to remove remote consumer Consumer -
Q:temporary_destination:__queue_10.61.3.98_48779_1:[consumer:526680979485571328,
type=NONE]:java.lang.RuntimeException: Cannot order unordered items

Other brokers saw this:

[19/Dec/2009:09:04:09 GMT] WARNING [B2224]: Unable to process remote acknowledgement
[45176735-207.171.14.52(d9:c9:bf:34:52:80)44379
1261213448625][consumer:9092527470612539648, type=AUTO_ACKNOWLEDGE]:[consumer:0,
type=AUTO_ACKNOWLEDGE] because [B4285]: Acknowledge message failed because its home broker
mq://207.171.14.53:7676/?
instName=jms1.lax.adconion.com&brokerSessionUID=3903817679257585664 has no response

Simply, the master broker had a very odd message, "Cannot order unordered items" after jms2.lax
decided to restart itself, which seemed to confuse it enough that jms1.muc and jms2.muc stopped
getting responses from it in a timely manner.

The jms restart at 17:18GMT put everything back into a working state. So the question is, why did
jms2.lax decide to restart itself? We had no one running any kind of stomp clients on this broker at that
time.
#### Environment
Operating System: Linux
Platform: PC
#### Affected Versions
[4.4u1]

title: Incorrect synchronization in IMQDirectService
body:
We are seeing the appserver (GF V3 with MQ 4.4u1) hang when initializing
multiple MQ connection pools – we end up having two threads modifying a hash
map at the same time, and the hash map gets corrupted, resulting in the hash map
code going into an infinite loop. (That is the classic symptom of the JDK hash
map code when used by two threads at the same time.)

The appserver is setting up two connection pools and initializing connections
within the pool. At the appserver level, that initialization is synchronized at
the pool level. But in the MQ code, the connection factory has only a single
instance of IMQDirectService that is shared between the factories. Hence,
multiple threads attempt to call IMQDirectService.createDirectConnection at the
same time, and the call to localConnectionList.put() at the same time by two
threads corrupts the hash map.
#### Environment
Operating System: All
Platform: All
#### Affected Versions
[4.4u1]

title: imqcmd shutdown bkr generates error in event log
body:
I have installed Message Queue 4.4 Broker and set it up as Windows Service
using the command imqsvcadmin install

I start the broker service using net start MQ4.4_Broker command.

When I stop the broker service using net stop MQ4.4 Broker command, the service
is stopped but there is an error which is logged in Windows Event Viewer
containing the following text:
Event Type: Error
Event Source: MQ4.4_Broker
Event Category: None
Event ID: 0
Date: 2/3/2010
Time: 2:46:18 AM
User: N/A
Computer: <HOSTNAME>
Description:
The description for Event ID ( 0 ) in Source ( MQ4.4_Broker ) cannot be found.
The local computer may not have the necessary registry information or
message DLL files to display messages from a remote computer.
You may be able to use the /AUXSOURCE= flag to retrieve this description;
see Help and Support for details.
The following information is part of the event:
Message Queue 4.4 Broker: SetServiceStatus: 6 The handle is invalid.
.

This is also present in the version 4.1\. I did not test other versions but
expect it to be present.

title: Session.close() and Connection.close() possibly do not behave correctly (i.e. inconformant to JSR-914)
NA
body:
* **Issue Imported From:** https://github.com/javaee/openmq/issues/44
* **Original Issue Raised By:**@glassfishrobot
* **Original Issue  Assigned To:** Unassigned
* **Original Issue  Closed By:**@glassfishrobot

title: NA
body:
@glassfishrobot Commented 
Reported by bmesserer@java.net

title: NA
body:
@glassfishrobot Commented 
bmesserer@java.net said:
As I just found out, the root cause of this is another possible (though in this
case I'm quite sure) Spec violation, again, JSR-914 say, in section "4.4.1
Closing a Session":
When a session is closed, there is no need to close its constituent message
producers and consumers. The session close is sufficient to signal the JMS
provider that all resources for the session should be released.

With OpenMQ, however, one needs to close the consumers BEFORE closing the
session to avoid the "javax.jms.IllegalStateException". This behavior doesn't
seem to conform to the quoted paragraph.
For reproduction use the test-program attached to the request and insert
"mc.close();" in the "while"-loop just before "s.close();" - the
exception/logwarning will disappear.

body:

nigeldeakin@java.net said:
Thanks for submitting this, and for the clear testcase.

This looks like a bug. A similar exception is seen when session.commit() is called.

Allocating it for more detailed investigation.

title: Misleading DMQ warning message with NullPointerException when useDMQ=false
body:
Let me describe our setup first. We run OpenMQ4.4u1\. We have a 4 broker
cluster, 2 brokers each in different colocation facilities. There is a 160ms
latency between the two. I will attach the configs for the brokers and the
script we use to manually create destinations, that way you can see the config
for each of them.

The executive summary is that we have "-o useDMQ=false" set on all destinations
and are no longer using temporary destinations for anything.

The issue that we are seeing is that seemingly randomly we will get the
following error message in stdout on one of the brokers in the colo that does
not have the master broker in it:

[26/Apr/2010:00:54:12 GMT] WARNING [B2090]: Unable to move message

{0}

to the
Dead Message Queue.:
java.lang.NullPointerException
at com.sun.messaging.jmq.jmsserver.core.PacketReference.getPacketObject
(PacketReference.java:729)
at com.sun.messaging.jmq.jmsserver.core.PacketReference.getPacket
(PacketReference.java:863)
at com.sun.messaging.jmq.jmsserver.core.Destination.markDead
(Destination.java:529)
at com.sun.messaging.jmq.jmsserver.core.Consumer.getAndFillNextPacket
(Consumer.java:961)
at com.sun.messaging.jmq.jmsserver.core.Session.fillNextPacket
(Session.java:707)
at
com.sun.messaging.jmq.jmsserver.service.imq.IMQIPConnection.fillNextPacket
(IMQIPConnection.java:1907)
at com.sun.messaging.jmq.jmsserver.service.imq.IMQIPConnection.writeData
(IMQIPConnection.java:1552)
at com.sun.messaging.jmq.jmsserver.service.imq.IMQIPConnection.process
(IMQIPConnection.java:529)
at com.sun.messaging.jmq.jmsserver.service.imq.OperationRunnable.process
(OperationRunnable.java:170)
at com.sun.messaging.jmq.jmsserver.util.pool.BasicRunnable.run
(BasicRunnable.java:493)
at java.lang.Thread.run(Thread.java:619)

Shortly after that, we see a message about closing the session between the two
brokers, then this error message:

[26/Apr/2010:01:09:45 GMT] ERROR [B3100]: Unexpected Broker Internal Error :
[Uncaught Exception]:
com.sun.messaging.jmq.jmsserver.util.BrokerException: [B4117]: Unexpected
Broker Exception: [Unexpected Error processing message]
at com.sun.messaging.jmq.jmsserver.data.PacketRouter.handleMessage
(PacketRouter.java:205)
at com.sun.messaging.jmq.jmsserver.service.imq.IMQIPConnection.readData
(IMQIPConnection.java:1355)
at com.sun.messaging.jmq.jmsserver.service.imq.IMQIPConnection.process
(IMQIPConnection.java:542)
at com.sun.messaging.jmq.jmsserver.service.imq.OperationRunnable.process
(OperationRunnable.java:170)
at com.sun.messaging.jmq.jmsserver.util.pool.BasicRunnable.run
(BasicRunnable.java:493)
at java.lang.Thread.run(Thread.java:619)

After that, it appears that the original broker is trying to connect to the
master broker, and the master broker is unable to process those messages. The
link stays "broken" until a restart. In the meantime, there are no error
messages in the other two brokers, which continue to forward messages like
always. This seems to result in topics filling up, due to consumers not marking
messages as read, according to the faulty brokers. Eventually, the whole system
breaks down, because we hit the destination message caps.

I will attach the relevant configs, the setup script, and the stdout of the two
brokers with issues. We have observed this behavior at least twice in the past
month.
#### Environment
Operating System: Linux
Platform: PC
#### Affected Versions
[4.4u1]

1\. The NullPointerException, appeared in both broker logs, is a WARNING log
message which is caused by GC and indicates the message has been expired while
attempting to be delivered to client, so it can be ignored,

[26/Apr/2010:00:54:12 GMT] WARNING [B2090]: Unable to move message

{0} to the
Dead Message Queue.

The warning message itself is misleading - it says "Dead Message Queue" but
actually only if useDMQ=true.

2\. The above NPE does not has any causal relation with closing "session" (link)
to the master broker, e.g. see timestamps
[09/Dec/2009:23:50:47 GMT] WARNING [B2090]: Unable to move message {0}

to the
Dead Message Queue.:

...... <==== omitted only stacktrace of the above NPE
[11/Dec/2009:18:13:08 GMT] [B1072]: Closed cluster connection to broker
mq://10.61.3.71:7676/?instName=jms2.muc.adconion.com&brokerSessionUID=7891473634949146880

in the master broker log,
[11/Dec/2009:18:16:34 GMT] [B1047]: Shutting down broker...

4\. In master broker log, there are many following warning messages, please
check your configuration setup and impact of these warnings on your application,

[02/Mar/2010:19:43:41 GMT] WARNING [B2007]: Creation of destination
amg.budget.reply.lax failed:
com.sun.messaging.jmq.jmsserver.util.BrokerException: [B2083]: Unable to create
destination amg.budget.reply.lax [Topic], autocreation is forbidden

5\. The broker logs indicate there might be intermittent network problems between
jms1.muc.adconion.com and the master broker for both broker logs show they can't
get responses from each other at about same time:

In jms1.muc.adconion.com broker log:
[26/Apr/2010:00:55:03 GMT] WARNING [B2062]: Lock request timed out for resid =
queue:amg.ddw.amg.muc_0.
Following brokers did not respond :

mq://207.171.14.53:7676/?instName=jms1.lax.adconion.com&brokerSessionUID=6332105265796570624

In jms1.lax.adconion.com broker log:

title: NA
body:
@glassfishrobot Commented 
mondokat@java.net said:
Ok, so a few comments.

First, the "unable to create destination" is an expected message. It occurs
because our application uses a spring library that tries to create a
destination if it doesn't exist, but we have autocreation turned off. We see
these messages when we stop the broker, delete its fs370 directory (for a
completely clean restart) and bring it back up. We then use the destination
creation script to manually create all destinations. Until that happens, we
expect to see many messages of this type.

As for intermittent connectivity, yes, it is a WAN link that occasionally gets
~4% packet loss. However, this loss seems to only have affected these two
brokers, and not the other two. They "weathered the storm" just fine. I don't
understand why.

Lastly, if the other messages are benign, why do we observe a constantly rising
total system message count after these errors occur? There is obviously a
correlation between at least one of these messages and the constantly
increasing total message count. Every time we see these error patterns, we see
the message count start rising. It is as if a consumer isn't reading from a
topic, except that all consumers seem to be behaving as if they read all
messages. The broker just doesn't recognize that fact.

title: C4072 msg includes key in exception message
body:
The set methods of the javax.jms.Message implementation return an exception with
the following message when passing null:

java.lang.IllegalArgumentException: C4072[C4072]: Illegal property name - "" or
null.

Note that the actual message includes the key of the message (the msg Id is
therefore listed twice).

It's because of the following code:

String errorString = AdministeredObject.cr.getKString(AdministeredObject.
cr.X_BAD_PROPERTY_NAME);

throw new IllegalArgumentException(AdministeredObject.cr.
X_BAD_PROPERTY_NAME + errorString);

getKString looks up the message (which includes the message prefix in brackets)
and in the exception the message key a prefixed to it again.

Easy fix:

mq/src/share/java/com/sun/messaging/jmq/jmsclient/MessageImpl.java
String errorString = AdministeredObject.cr.getKString(AdministeredObject.
cr.X_BAD_PROPERTY_NAME);

*   throw new IllegalArgumentException(AdministeredObject.cr.
*   X_BAD_PROPERTY_NAME + errorString);
    + throw new IllegalArgumentException(errorString);
    }

//Verify properties are writeable
#### Environment
Operating System: All
Platform: All
#### Affected Versions
[4.5]

title: jms concurrency issue where messages stuck on queue
body:
I am getting problems processing large numbers of messages on Glassfish with
OpenMQ using multiple stateless session beans consuming messages concurrently from
an OpenMQ queue. This issue is identical to the symptoms described in glassfish
issue 4222, although in this case we are not using selectors at all. I am
reposting the issue here, as I suspect from our tests that this may be a
concurrency issue within open mq. Please find the details of the bug and analysis
we have already performed on the glassfish issue tracker here:

[https://glassfish.dev.java.net/issues/show_bug.cgi?id=11961](https://glassfish.dev.java.net/issues/show_bug.cgi?id=11961)
#### Environment
Operating System: Windows XP
Platform: PC
#### Affected Versions
[4.4u1]

body:
@glassfishrobot Commented 
slossr@java.net said:
I have found that if I force the consumerFlowLimit to be 1, which I had to do by
making a code change (see [https://mq.dev.java.net/issues/show_bug.cgi?id=51](https://mq.dev.java.net/issues/show_bug.cgi?id=51)), that
all messages are consumed from the queue without issue. It does not handle
multiple consumers fetching from a queue concurrently if the fetch limit is high
and all messages are not consumed from those fetched for that QueueSession. When
the fetched messages that were not consumed are put back onto the queue, if
another thread has been concurrently accessing the queue and found it to be empty,
it appears to set the current and next element to null, causing those messages
returned by the first thread to then get stuck on the queue.

title: consumerFlowLimit property is ignored
body:
Setting property "consumerFlowLimit" on a queue has no effect when consuming
from a queue synchronously. I am using OpenMQ 4.4 build 16 which comes bundled
with GlassFish 2.1.1\. My client app reads a single message from the queue via a
stateless session bean before releasing the session and is being run with
multiple concurrent consumers. The result is that each consumer picks up 1000
messages (default prefetch), consumes one, and then puts the remaining 999
messages back onto the queue. With multiple threads the queue eventually becomes
corrupted (due to a separate issue â€“ see
[https://mq.dev.java.net/issues/show_bug.cgi?id=50](https://mq.dev.java.net/issues/show_bug.cgi?id=50)).

I have set consumerFlowLimit to 1 on my queue (as well as on the connection pool
used within GlassFish), which I hoped would get around this problem and perhaps
improve performance, however this property appears to be ignored and each
consumer is still picking up 1000 messages from the queue.

During debugging I found the following code in IMQDirectService.addConsumer()
which explains this behaviour:
int size = -1;
....
/*

*   size (prefetch size) is not needed here since the broker is going to
*   call the client method with the messages, not simply dump packets
*   till a particular size is reached.
    */
    con = protocol.createConsumer(d, cxn,
    session, selector, clientId,
    durableName, noLocal, size,
    shared, new Object().toString(), acEnabled);

The size variable is eventually passed into ConsumerHandler.createConsumer()
where it is used to calculate prefetch. The hard-coded value of -1 effectively
means that the prefetch value set on the queue (i.e. consumerMessageFlow
property) is ignored:

int cprefetch = size;
int dprefetch = (wildcard ? -1 : (!shared
? d.getMaxPrefetch()
: d.getSharedConsumerFlowLimit()));

prefetch = (dprefetch == -1) ?
cprefetch :
(cprefetch == -1 ? cprefetch
: (cprefetch > dprefetch?
dprefetch : cprefetch));
c.setPrefetch(prefetch);
#### Environment
Operating System: Windows XP
Platform: PC
#### Affected Versions
[4.4]

title: NA
NA
body:
@glassfishrobot Commented 
nigeldeakin@java.net said:
Now fixed (will be released in MQ 4.5 Milestone 2).

The queue property consumerFlowLimit (for an administratively-created queue), or
the broker property imq.autocreate.queue.consumerFlowLimit (for an auto-ccreated
queue) will now be used to configure the size of blocks in which messages are
pre-sent to the JMSRA direct mode client.

Note that although these properties have a similar behaviour to when TCP mode
clients are used, the behaviour is not identical, since flow control (in which
the broker pauses the delivery of messages and waits for a "resume packet" from
the client) is not required or performed when the direct mode client is used. In
particular, consumerFlowThreshold is not used to determine when the next "block"
of messages needs to be pre-fetched. Instead, the next block of messages is
prefetched when the previous block is exhausted.

Note also that although the "options" parameter of the ManagedConnectionFactory
allows MQ connection factory properties to be specified, these are all ignored
when JMSRA direct mode is being used. In consequence, the connection factory
property imqConsumerFlow limit cannot be configured.

title: Dynamically update clients when a broker joins or leaves a conventional cluster
body:
This enhancement request proposes that when a broker joins or leaves a
conventional cluster, any existing clients are automatically notified so their
addressList can be updated.

This allows existing clients to failover to newly-added brokers which they would
otherwise not be aware of.

This functionality is already present for enhanced clusters.

Since this would override any addressList already used by the client we may wish
to make this behaviour configurable by setting a connection factory property.
#### Environment
Operating System: All
Platform: All
#### Affected Versions
[5.0]

title: easier configuration of ConnectionFactory in Spring contexts
body:
Currrently (4.4u1), configuration of a ConnectionFactory in a Spring XML context
is cumbersome, because ConnectionFactory does not support either constructor or
setter injection of its properties. (It's slightly funny that a SUN project does
not follow JavaBeans conventions). Instead one has to use
factory.setProperty(String name, String value). To do this in Spring one has to
write a custom ConnectionFactoryFactoryBean that calls this method for all
properties.
Proposal: add a method setProperties(Map<String, String> properties) to
com.sun.messaging.AdministeredObject that iteraties over the map and calls
setProperty(String, String) for each entry. Then a Spring context could simply
look like this:

<bean id="jmsConnectionFactory" class="com.sun.messaging.ConnectionFactory">
<property name="properties">
<util:map>
<entry key="imqAddressList" value="mq://localhost:7676/jms"/>
<entry key="imqDefaultUsername" value="jmsuser"/>
<entry key="imqDefaultPassword" value="secret"/>
</util:map>
</property>
</bean>
#### Environment
Operating System: All
Platform: All
#### Affected Versions
[current]

title: support for running openmq as a active-passive cluster over a cluster filesystem
body:
A cheap way to create a high available OpenMQ configuration is to run OpenMQ in
an active/passive configuration over a shared filesystem. One node grabs the
global lock and the other node blocks until lock become available again (when
the first node stops or crashes). Clients have the URLs of both brokers in the
address list and will reconnect to the broker that has become active.
ActiveMQ supports this under the name 'Shared File System Master Slave' (see
[http://activemq.apache.org/shared-file-system-master-slave.html](http://activemq.apache.org/shared-file-system-master-slave.html)).
OpenMQ can very easily support this configuration too: it already has a global
instance lock var/mq/instances/imqbroker/lock. Currently, if OpenMQ cannot
acquire the lock it exists.
Proposal: Modify com.sun.messaging.jmq.jmsserver.util.LockFile to optionally
wait until it has acquired the lock. Add a configuration property to turn on
this behavior.
#### Environment
Operating System: All
Platform: All
#### Affected Versions
[current]

title: support logging to Syslog on other platforms than Solaris
body:
The current SysLogHandler uses a native Solaris library to perform logging to
syslog. This ulimits support for logging to syslog to the Solaris platform.
Particularly on other Unix-like system such as Linux logging to syslog would be
very useful.
Plenty open source SyslogLogger implementations are available, e.g. log4,
logback or custom Loggers for java.util.logging.
Proposal: either reimplement the com.sun.messaging.jmq.util.log.SysLog class in
pure Java to send messages tot syslog via UDP,
or, preferably, add a Logger that delegates logging to log4j, logback, slf4j,
java.util.logging or similar.
#### Environment
Operating System: All
Platform: All
#### Affected Versions
[current]

title: when store transacted sent persist Queue message,  pre-allocate space for interest state
body:
This bug was also created a bug id 6950583 on Sun bug database.

The problem was reproduced against the OpenMQ bundled with Glassfish v3.

Reproduction:

1\. Prepare a disk(e.g. F drive.) whose free space is set to about 18M.

2\. Start broker

=====
E:\glassfish\imq\bin>imqbrokerd -varhome F:\imq
=====

3\. Start Glassfish app server
To change the settings of Java Message Service and JMS Resources as follows:
=====

*   Set Java Message Service Type to [REMOTE] (admin01.jpg)
*   Define [jms/MyQueueConnectionFactory] at Connection Factories,
    and set Transaction Support to [LocalTransaction]. (admin02.jpg)
*   Define [jms/MyQueue] at Destination Resources,
    and set name property to [JMSDEMOQueue]. (admin03.jpg)
    =====

4\. Deploy attached sender.war
5\. Access [http://localhost:8080/sender/](http://localhost:8080/sender/)
The messages will be sent.
6\. Push button several times and make the disk full.
The error message will be thrown at broker prompt.
=====
[06/5/2010:10:39:19 JST] ERROR [B4105]: Failed to persist interest list for
message 132-10.209.11.117(ce:d3:4:4f:fe:c4)-1911-1273109959515
=====

7\. Confirm the message of Unacknowledge remained in the queue.
=====
E:\glassfish\imq\bin>imqcmd list dst
Username: admin
Password: admin
Listing all the destinations on the broker specified by:

-------------------------
Host Primary Port
-------------------------
localhost 7676

---------------------------------------------------------------------------
Name Type State Producers Consumers Msgs
Total Count UnAck Avg Size
---------------------------------------------------------------------------
JMSDEMOQueue Queue RUNNING 0 0 11 1 1000164.0
mq.sys.dmq Queue RUNNING 0 0 0 0 0.0

Successfully listed destinations.

E:\glassfish\imq\bin>
=====

One suggested fix plan that is target to glassfish v2 ur2.
Please see this suggestion below and give any comments.

------------
I have tested the OpenMQ with this fix and did not see any problem with minimal
tests.
Current Implementation:
1\. The VR file is growing with the allocateSize + RECORD_HEADER_SIZE.
2\. After growing the file it allocate the increased memory for storing the
messages and the VR FilePointer is also increasing.
3\. But this file size allocation is happening with allocateSize only.

It means the file size is increased but few space(RECORD_HEADER_SIZE) is not
allocated. That is why, send operation happens successfully because there is a
space in VR file. But fails while committing the message because this time
broker tries to write interests state and even though there is a space broker
tries to increase the file size and the exception occurs in broker.

File name: VRFileRAF.java
Method name: allocate(int size)
Line number: 293

288 if (remaining() < allocateSize)

{ 289 // grow file 290 growfile(allocateSize + RECORD_HEADER_SIZE); 291 }

292
293 record = getNewSlice(allocateSize);

The proposed 293 line will be:

293 record = getNewSlice(allocateSize + RECORD_HEADER_SIZE);

---------------
#### Environment
Operating System: Windows XP
Platform: All
#### Affected Versions
[4.4u1]
