title: NA
body:
@glassfishrobot Commented 
amyk@java.net said:
1\. The reason for passing 'allocateSize' not 'allocateSize + RECORD_HEADER_SIZE'
in below code is because the RECORD_HEADER_SIZE is allocated for the
lastrecordHeader (see VRFileRAF.getNewSliceAndWrite)

288 if (remaining() < allocateSize)

{ 289 // grow file 290 growfile(allocateSize + RECORD_HEADER_SIZE); 291 }

292
293 record = getNewSlice(allocateSize);

2\. The store does not attempt to pre-allocate space for a message's interest
states when persist a transacted message, therefore if disk is full, IOException
can happen when store message's interest.

3\. Since the message itself has been persisted, the message is not lost (it
should be re-routed when the broker restarts)

4\. For transacted sent Queue message, when persisting a message, space for its
interest state can be pre-allocated. This can be an enhancement for Queue messages

title: StringIndex out of bounds in DBManager if tables with short names are found
body:
If the persistence tables are located in a tablespace/schema (or whatever the
Oracle mumbo jumbo used to define a place tables are hosted is called) where
tables with names shorter than two characters exist the
com.sun.messaging.jmq.jmsserver.persist.jdbc.DBManager throws a
StringIndexOutOfBounds exception when parsing table names.
: [26/Aug/2010:13:50:15 CEST] ERROR [B3000]: Could not open persistent message
store:
com.sun.messaging.jmq.jmsserver.util.BrokerException: [B3100]: Unexpected Broker
Internal Error : [Unable to retry database operation]
at
com.sun.messaging.jmq.jmsserver.persist.jdbc.Util$RetryStrategy.assertShouldRetry(Util.java:682)
at
com.sun.messaging.jmq.jmsserver.persist.jdbc.DBManager.getTableNamesFromDB(DBManager.java:880)
at
com.sun.messaging.jmq.jmsserver.persist.jdbc.DBManager.checkStoreExists(DBManager.java:802)
at
com.sun.messaging.jmq.jmsserver.persist.jdbc.JDBCStore.checkStore(JDBCStore.java:3602)
at com.sun.messaging.jmq.jmsserver.persist.jdbc.JDBCStore.<init>(JDBCStore.java:127)
at sun.reflect.NativeConstructorAccessorImpl.newInstance0(Native Method)
at
sun.reflect.NativeConstructorAccessorImpl.newInstance(NativeConstructorAccessorImpl.java:39)
at
sun.reflect.DelegatingConstructorAccessorImpl.newInstance(DelegatingConstructorAccessorImpl.java:27)
at java.lang.reflect.Constructor.newInstance(Constructor.java:513)
at java.lang.Class.newInstance0(Class.java:355)
at java.lang.Class.newInstance(Class.java:308)
at
com.sun.messaging.jmq.jmsserver.persist.StoreManager.getStore(StoreManager.java:157)
at com.sun.messaging.jmq.jmsserver.Globals.getStore(Globals.java:975)
at com.sun.messaging.jmq.jmsserver.Broker._start(Broker.java:840)
at com.sun.messaging.jmq.jmsserver.Broker.start(Broker.java:410)
at com.sun.messaging.jmq.jmsserver.Broker.main(Broker.java:1973)
Caused by: java.lang.StringIndexOutOfBoundsException: String index out of range: 1
at java.lang.String.charAt(String.java:687)
at
com.sun.messaging.jmq.jmsserver.persist.jdbc.DBManager.getTableNamesFromDB(DBManager.java:862)
... 14 more

The metadata from the database (oracle in this case, and user's rights might be
higher than what is required) returns all table names.
In the method called getTableNamesFromDB a StringIndexOutOfBoundException is
thrown when a table named with one character (Â´AÂ´ in this case) is found and the
name is being parsed to check whether it starts with "MQ"
line #864 in the 4.4u1 source code will throw the afore mentioned exception if
the table name<2.
I suggest a check using String.startsWith("MQ") prior to adding the table to the
HashMap tableNames or a check to see whether the length of tableName>1
#### Environment
Operating System: All
Platform: All
#### Affected Versions
[4.4u1]

title: jmsbridge (with XA link) enabled HA broker can't be halted when false takeover occurred
body:
We are running Sun Message Queue in an HA-Cluster with two nodes on Windows
Server 2003 with Oracle 10.2 persistence.

In situations with very extreme high load on the server (not on Sun MQ) hosting
node1, node2 can't receive heartbeat from node1\. Node2 starts to monitor node1s
status and after monitor-threshold invocations it starts the takeover process
for node1\. But node1 is still running and (after high load is reduced) receives
messages and stores the messages on the queue. But these messages disappear when
we restart node1 in order to get the cluster running again.

Obviously these messages are not persisted correctly.

Node1 can't get back into the cluster without restart because it is rejected by
node2:
[19/Okt/2010:13:13:56 MESZ] WARNUNG [B2119]: Clusterverbindung zu
Address = mq://10.86.128.13:7676/?instName=TIBCO_TEST1&brokerID=TIBCO_TE
ST1&brokerSessionUID=5321895505967462400&ha=true&storeSessionUID=532189550596746
2400
StartTime = 1287485452516
ProtocolVersion = 410
HeartbeatHost = 10.86.128.13
HeartbeatPort = 7676 wird zur<FC>ckgewiesen. Es handelt es sich um ein
<DC>bernahmeziel.
[19/Okt/2010:13:13:56 MESZ] [B1072]: Cluster-Verbindung zu Broker mq://10.86.128
.13:7676/?instName=TIBCO_TEST1&brokerID=TIBCO_TEST1&brokerSessionUID=53218955059
#### Environment
Operating System: other
Platform: Other
#### Affected Versions
[4.4u1]

title: NA
body:
@glassfishrobot Commented 
amyk@java.net said:
1\. For HA-cluster (enhanced cluster), you should at least use 4.4u2\. 4.4u2 has
fixes for important issues (including 6898355, 6926974, etc.) regarding broker
restart after takeover

2\. Set cluster failure detection property appropriate to you network and load.
Low values of imq.cluster.monitor.interval and imq.cluster.monitor.threshold
would increase the chance of false takeover
[http://docs.sun.com/app/docs/doc/821-1794/gguju?l=en&a=view](http://docs.sun.com/app/docs/doc/821-1794/gguju?l=en&a=view)

3\. When a broker detects a "split-brain" situation, it will halt and restart itself.

title: NA
body:
@glassfishrobot Commented 
oholzma@java.net said:
Thank you for the immediate response.

I installed 4.4u2 but no change in behaviour. The broker detects Split-Brain and
tries to shut down. But shut down doesn't work, the broker still receives messages.

I disabled all message bridges and retested again. Now the broker stops
immediately at Split-Brain-Situation and restarted again.

Is there an issue with shutdown when bridgemanager and bridges are enabled?

FMM: Freeing mismatched memory
This is occurring while in thread 18541:
operator delete(void*) [rtlib.o]
freeTableOp [BasicTypeHashtable.cpp: ...]
......
Attempting to free block at 0x80d94a0 in the heap.
Address 0x80d94a0 is at the beginning of a malloc'd block of 32 bytes.
This block was allocated from thread 18541:
malloc [rtlib.o]
operator new(unsigned) [libstdc++.so.6]
......
This block of memory was obtained using an allocation routine which is
not compatible with the routine by which it is being freed.
FMM: Freeing mismatched memory

gcc version 3.4.6 20060404 (Red Hat 3.4.6-9)
PurifyPlus.7.0.1.0-002

title: url service improperly set
body:
Hi,

I am using version : 4.4 Update 2 Patch 1 (Build 1-c) that comes integrated with Glassfish.

I am setting up glassfish with REMOTE jms type in order to have all MB's running on a single blade and thus having the 'single point of failure' set into one place.

In order to do that I create some scripts to start the MB's on that blade.

Here is the command line that I use:

```
/bin/sh \
  /opt/sailfin/imq/bin/imqbrokerd \
    -javahome /opt/java \
    -Dimq.log.file.rolloverbytes=2000000 \
    -Dimq.jms.min_threads=10 \
    -Dimq.jms.max_threads=1000 \
    -Dimq.admin.max_threads=12 \
    -Dimq.hostname=primary_sc \
    -Dimq.cluster.hostname=primary_sc -Dimq.cluster.clusterid=traffic \
    -Dimq.cluster.masterbroker=mq://primary_sc:37677/ \
    -Dimq.cluster.brokerlist=mq://primary_sc:37677/ \
    -Dimq.cluster.nowaitForMasterBroker=true \
    -varhome /opt/sailfin/nodedata/nodeagents/primary_sc/MB_traffic_instance/imq \
    -startRmiRegistry \
    -rmiRegistryPort 37777 \
    -Dimq.imqcmd.user=admin \
    -passfile /home/mmas/imqpassword.dat \
    -save \
    -name MBtraffictrafficinstance \
    -port 37677 \
    -bgnd \
    -silent
```

What I found bizar is that even if I set '-Dimq.hostname=primary_sc' I do see in the log.txt file the following :

```
[26/Jan/2011:20:05:23 EST] JMX Connector Server jmxrmi started successfully with url service:jmx:rmi://SC-2-1/jndi/rmi://primary_sc:37777/primary_sc/37677/jmxrmi
```

The error to me is the "SC-2-1" definition ! I think it should be 'primary_sc' !

I think that the url should be : "service:jmx:rmi://primary_SC/jndi/rmi://primary_sc:37777/primary_sc/37677/jmxrmi"

The blade has multiple interfaces && the hostname is 'SC-2-1' BUT it is refered as 'primary_sc' which is a 'movable' ip for HA at the service controller level.

Behaviour wise it seems that all ok but I am not sure since I do not have an app to test RMI.

BR,
Dan S.
#### Affected Versions
[4.4u2]

title: exception when loading destination on ADD_CONSUMER is not propagated
body:
When exception occurs on loading destination when ADD_CONSUMER, the destination is unloaded but the exception is not propagated. As a consequence, the client, GlassFish server in the following case, does not know the destination that the client consumer is to consume messages from was failed to load. The following is a case of GlassFish MDB deployment with EMBEDDED broker when there is no sufficient memory to load all the messages from the destination. The user can only discover the failure by examing the server log.

title: JMX  changeMasterBroker operation: possible status codes need to be defined as static constants
body:
In the JMX API, the cluster configuration MBean has an operation changeMasterBroker, which returns an integer status code if an error occurs.

Depending on the value of this status code the user's program needs to take different action. To allow this, the possible status codes need to be made available as static constants in the JMX API.

The possible status codes are

400 BAD_REQUEST
405 NOT_ALLOWED
503 UNAVAILABLE
412 PRECONDITION_FAILED

The above constants should added to the utility class ChangeMasterBrokerResultInfo (though a different class could be used if this was thought preferable).

This will allow the user's program to distinguish between the above errors (which mean the cluster's config was unchanged) and any other errors (which means there was an unknown error requiring a cluster shutdown and manual configuration).

When this has been done, the Developer's Guide for JMX Clients needs to be updated to refer to these constants, and the appropriate behaviour.
#### Affected Versions
[4.5]

title: NA
NA
body:
@glassfishrobot Commented 
@nigeldeakin said:
This has been implemented using a new ConnectionFactory property imqSocketConnectTimeout. This should be documented in the MQ admin guide as follows:

**Property**: imqSocketConnectTimeout

**Description**: This property defines the socket timeout, in milliseconds, used when a TCP connection is made to the broker. A timeout of zero is interpreted as an infinite timeout. The connection will then block until established or an error occurs. This property is used when connecting to the port mapper as well as when connecting to the required service.

**Default value**: 0

In previous versions of MQ the socket timeout could be configured by setting the system property imqSocketConnectTimeout, though this feature was undocumented and is unsupported. This feature remains available but continues to be undocumented and unsupported. For backwards compatibility, a value set using the system property imqSocketConnectTimeout will not be overridden if the property imqSocketConnectTimeout is set on the connection factory.

In addition, the MQ admin console imqadmin has been changed as shown in the attached screenshot. The Connection Factory Object properties dialog, Connection Handling tab, now has a new input field (at the bottom) for "TCP Socket Connection Timeout (milliseconds)". The online help needs to be updated to describe the new property.

title: Update client addressList when a GlassFish-managed broker is added/removed to/from the cluster
body:
This feature request describes code changes to ensure that when a broker is added to, or removed from, a conventional broker cluster being managed by GlassFish, the addressList property used by all existing and future connections to that cluster are updated to reflect the addition or removal of the broker. This means that in the event of a broker failure each connection to that broker can failover to any of the remaining brokers in the cluster, and that time is not wasted trying to failover to brokers that no longer exist.

For full and definitive detail of this feature please see the appropriate one-pager, which overrides the any detail included in this JIRA issue.

This change is needed to support the elasticity of managed MQ brokers in GlassFish 3.2.

The basic requirement here is to ensure that client connections to clustered brokers always hold an up-to-date list of the brokers in the cluster in order to ensure that in the event of connection failure the connection can failover to any of the remaining brokers in the cluster, and that time is not wasted trying to failover to brokers that no longer exist.

This requirement only applies in the following case:

*   Where the brokers in the cluster have their lifecycle managed by GlassFish. (Although similar behaviour would be desirable for
    non-managed broker clusters, this is not currently a requirement.)
*   Where the client connections are running in GlassFish and created using the JMSRA resource adapter. (Although similar behaviour would certainly be desirable for standalone client connections using the MQ client, this is outside the scope of this one-pager.)
*   For conventional clusters. (This behaviour is already available when using enhanced clusters, which are "self-configuring" and each client is automatically updated to hold an up-to-date list of the brokers in the cluster.)

In the standalone MQ client, the list of brokers in the cluster is set using the connection factory attribute <tt>imqAddressList</tt>. However where the client connection is created using the JMSRA resource adapter this property is set not by users but by JMSRA using the resource adapter property <tt>connectionURL</tt>, which may be overridden by setting the <tt>addressList</tt> property on an individual managed connection factory or activation spec.

Here is a summary of the existing behaviour in GlassFish 3.1 when using a conventional cluster:

*   When each GlassFish instance is started, the GlassFish JMS module sets the following properties on the JMSRA resource adapter. Note that these two properties are similar but not the same:
    *   <tt>connectionURL</tt> is set to a comma-separated list that defines the addressing scheme, host and port for each broker in the cluster. For example: <tt>mq://machine1:7676/jms,mq://machine2:7676/jms</tt>. The local broker should be the first in this list. JMSRA uses this property to set the <tt>imqAddressList</tt> of any connections made to that broker, unless it has been overridden by setting the <tt>addressList</tt> property on an individual managed connection factory or activation spec.
    *   <tt>clusterBrokerList</tt> is set to a comma-separated list of brokers in the cluster. For example: <tt>machine1:7676,machine2:7676</tt>. JMSRA uses this property to set the <tt>imq.cluster.brokerlist</tt> property of the managed local or embedded broker, both when it is first startedand when a local broker is restarted.
*   Whenever an instance is added to, or removed from, the GlassFish cluster, the GlassFish JMS module updates the <tt>clusterBrokerList</tt> of every resource adapter instance in the cluster with the new list of brokers. The RA uses this information only if it is managing a embedded or local broker, and uses it for the following purpose:
    *   It will save this information and use it to set <tt>imq.cluster.brokerlist</tt> when starting a managed (local or embedded) broker or when restarting a local broker.
    *   It uses a private protocol to send this information to the broker in order to update its <tt>imq.cluster.brokerlist</tt> property.

**Important:** Note that if cluster elasticity is required when the brokers are remote (which is explicitly out of scope for this one-pager), GlassFish must also set or update the <tt>clusterBrokerList</tt> in this case.

Although the above behaviour will ensure that the brokers have an up to date <tt>imq.cluster.brokerlist</tt> there is currently no mechanism
to ensure that existing and future connections have an up to date <tt>addressList</tt>. To achieve this the following additional behaviour is required:

*   Whenever an instance is added to, or removed from, the GlassFish cluster, the GlassFish JMS module updates the <tt>connectionURL</tt> of every resource adapter instance in the cluster to reflect the added or removed broker. The RA will use this information only if it is managing a embedded or local broker, and uses it for the following purpose:
    *   It will save this information and use it to set <tt>imqAddressListlist</tt> of any connections that are subsequently created unless it was overridden by setting the <tt>addressList</tt> property on an individual managed connection factory or activation spec.
    *   It uses it to update the <tt>imqAddressListlist</tt> of any existing connection factories.
    *   It uses a private protocol to send this information to the broker, which will then sent it to all its connected clients to update their <tt>imqAddressListlist</tt>,

**Important:** Note that if cluster elasticity is required when the brokers are remote (which is explicitly out of scope for this one-pager), GlassFish must also set or update the <tt>connectionURL</tt> in this case.
**TODO:** Define private protocol by which RA sends <tt>connectionURL</tt> to broker, and broker sends <tt>imqAddressListlist</tt> to existing connections.
#### Affected Versions
[4.1, 4.2, 4.3, 4.4, 4.4u1, 4.4u2, 4.5, 4.5.1, 4.5.2]

Actually we have used in this OpenMQ API C libraries in a web application and it is worked fine with the 32 bit windows environment. (Target platform as Any CPU). Fixed in Document Source.

imqSocketConnectTimeout Long integer 0 Socket timeout, in milliseconds, used when a TCP connection is made to the broker
This value applies when connecting to the port mapper as well as when connecting to the required service.
The timeout value 0 (zero) denotes an infinite timeout, in which case the connection will block until it is established or an error occurs.

title: Client using mq://localhost/direct not thrown exception when writing to a full queue
body:
This bug reported on the forum at [http://forums.oracle.com/forums/thread.jspa?forumID=874&threadID=2228870&messageID=9617861#9617861](http://forums.oracle.com/forums/thread.jspa?forumID=874&threadID=2228870&messageID=9617861#9617861)

This bug relates to the use of an embedded broker with direct mode client, as documented in the Message Queue "Developers Guide for Java Clients", chapter 6 "Embedding a Message Queue Broker in a Java Client".

If a queue has its maximum size defined using the destination property maxNumMsgs (for administratively-created queues) or the broker property imq.autocreate.destination.maxNumMsgs (for auto-created queues), then when that limit is reached, a TCP client receives a com.sun.messaging.jms.ResourceAllocationException (as documented in Table 18-1 "Physical Destination Properties" of the Message Queue Admin Guide). However a direct mode client does not receive any exception. The broker logs an error and rejects the new messages, but no exception is thrown to the client.

This is demonstrated using the attached test case. Before running it, set the broker args on line 81.

The test case as attached uses a TCP connection, and the exception thrown is

```
com.sun.messaging.jmq.jmsserver.util.BrokerException: [B4120]: Can not store message
14-10.175.12.175(e7:77:6f:2c:9a:97)-3715-1306435265343 on destination curlyQueue [Queue]. 
The destination message count limit (maxNumMsgs) of 100 has been reached.
Exception in thread "main" com.sun.messaging.jms.ResourceAllocationException: [C4096]: Destination is full 
and is rejecting new messages: curlyQueue user=guest, broker=localhost:7676(3711)
	at com.sun.messaging.jmq.jmsclient.ProtocolHandler.writeJMSMessage(ProtocolHandler.java:2001)
	at com.sun.messaging.jmq.jmsclient.WriteChannel.sendWithFlowControl(WriteChannel.java:179)
	at com.sun.messaging.jmq.jmsclient.WriteChannel.writeJMSMessage(WriteChannel.java:132)
	at com.sun.messaging.jmq.jmsclient.SessionImpl.writeJMSMessage(SessionImpl.java:795)
	at com.sun.messaging.jmq.jmsclient.MessageProducerImpl.writeJMSMessage(MessageProducerImpl.java:213)
	at com.sun.messaging.jmq.jmsclient.MessageProducerImpl.writeJMSMessage(MessageProducerImpl.java:202)
	at com.sun.messaging.jmq.jmsclient.MessageProducerImpl.send(MessageProducerImpl.java:689)
	at com.sun.messaging.jmq.jmsclient.QueueSenderImpl.send(QueueSenderImpl.java:128)
	at maxnummsgs.TestClient.main(TestClient.java:47)
```

Now uncomment line 35 (which sets the imqAddressList property to mq://localhost/direct) and repeat the test. No such exception is thrown.
#### Affected Versions
[4.5]

title: Administration Guide:  typo on imqdbmgr restore command syntax
body:
MQ Administration Guide 4.5 p197
To restore the data store from these files, use the command
imqdbmgr restore -restore backupDir

'-restore' should be '-dir'

and also the documentation should say that all brokers in the enhanced cluster should have shutdown before run this command
#### Affected Versions
[4.5]

#97

* * *

where backupDir is the path to the directory in which to place the backup files. To restore the data store from these files, use the command

imqdbmgr restore -dir backupDir

Before restoring the data store, you should shut down all brokers in the enhanced cluster.

title: Performance regression in MQ start-up from GF v2.1.1 to 3.1.1
body:
We have a significant regression in server start-up and deployment of an EJB app from GlassFish 2.1.1 to 3.1.1\.

Amit in the performance group has gathered some collector/analyzer profiles for this (and some other) workloads. I've been looking at them, and although much of the code base has changed radically there are some similarities.

One example: During start-up of the EJB container, 3.1.1 spends 1.251 CPU seconds in com.sun.enterprise.connectors.ActiveRAFactory.createActiveResourceAdapter. In v2.1.1 we spend only 0.590 CPU seconds in the same method.

Drilling down into the call trees, it looks as if a major difference in com.sun.messaging.jmq.jmsserver.Broker.start. In v2.1.1 we spend 0.500 CPU seconds in that method, whereas in 3.1.1 we spend 0.991 CPU seconds.

I will attach text files showing the analyzer output from the profiles of the two versions.

Is it possible to ask the same profiling of broker startup to compare with or without following broker property setting ?

or set this property to the broker instance's config.properties file.

title: JMSRA ActivationSpec property endpointPoolResizeTimeout should allow zero value
body:
This fix is needed as part of the solution to [GLASSFISH-4629](http://java.net/jira/browse/GLASSFISH-4629)
- eclipse-ee4j/glassfish#4629

Currently, com.sun.messaging.jms.ra.ActivationSpec.setEndpointPoolResizeTimeout(int endpointPoolResizeTimeout) will throw an IllegalArgumentException if a value of 0 is supplied, meaning "infinite timeout".

JMSRA does not use this value. The current behaviour is that endpoints do not timeout, so in fact a value of 0 corresponds to the current behaviour but is not allowed.
#### Affected Versions
[4.5]

title: imqadmin object store - admin objects disappear if name contains / character
body:
Administered objects with lookup names that contain a / character disappear from the admin console GUI on refresh or reconnection to the object store.

The objects exist within the store, and can be access via JNDI, they are just not visible within the admin console.

Please see detailed description at [http://forums.oracle.com/forums/thread.jspa?threadID=2251316&tstart=0](http://forums.oracle.com/forums/thread.jspa?threadID=2251316&tstart=0)
#### Environment
Windows 7, Glassfih 3.1 (including OpenMQ 4.5 build 29-b)
#### Affected Versions
[4.5]

title: Embedded broker startup errors do not throw an exception
body:
This issue concerns the use of embedded brokers, either in GlassFish when using JMSRA, or when using the embedded broker API. In both cases, if a <tt>BrokerException</tt> is thrown during broker startup, this is simply logged without throwing an exception to JMSRA or the application using the embedded broker API.

The reason is that if <tt>Broker._start</tt> encounters a <tt>BrokerException</tt> (e.g. due to imq.brokerid not being set for a JDBC store), it catches the exception, logs it, and then returns a value of 1\.

Meanwhile, <tt>BrokerInstanceImpl.start()</tt> ignores this return value. This means that JMSRA or the application using the embedded broker API is left in an undefined state without JMSRA or the application knowing that something has gone wrong.

The fix is to change <tt>BrokerInstanceImpl.start()</tt> to check the return code from Broker.start() and throw a <tt>RuntimeException</tt> if it is non-zero.

This will then be caused by JMSRA (<tt>LifecycleManagedBroker.start()</tt> which will convert it into a <tt>ResourceAdapterInternalException</tt>.

The fix should be tested in both GlassFish and by an application using the embedded broker API.
#### Affected Versions
[4.5]

30 messages not expired from destination my_queue [Queue] because they have been delivered to client at time of the last expiration reaping

30 messages in destination my_queue [Queue] that should be reaped due to expiration are not being reaped because they've been delivered to the client but haven't been acked or rolled back.

@amykang2020 said:
The 2nd NPE is fixed in 5.0.1\. The NPE is triggered by following SQLException when storing the DMQ to the user defined MQDST41 table

SQLException: [INSERT INTO MQDST41Ca5 ( ID, DESTINATION, IS_LOCAL, CONNECTION_ID, CONNECTED_TS, STORE_SESSION_ID, CREATED_TS) VALUES ( ?, ?, ?, ?, ?, ?, ? )]: String or binary data would be truncated.[22001, 8152]

This SQLException is caused by too small size of DESTINATION column - 1024\. Debugging shows that the Destination object to be stored, after serialization, has size=1153 (pos=2 mq.sys.dmq [Queue]). Increasing this column's size to 2048 works.

.....
DESTINATION VARBINARY(1024) NOT NULL,\

title: enhanced cluster should based on total time elaped since a broker become indoubt to determine takeover
body:
After broker becomes indoubt from UDP heartbeat timeout, the HA monitor counts the monitor iterations based on imq.cluster.monitor.threshold to determine takeover
imq.cluster.monitor.interval
imq.cluster.monitor.threshold

depending on the timing of UDP heartbeat timeout and the time it takes in last minitor run, the total monitor time before takeover action can be more than 1 monitor interval less than monitor-interval*monitor-threshold
#### Affected Versions
[4.1, 4.2, 4.3, 4.4, 4.4u1, 4.4u2, 4.5]

title: MQ Transaction reaper slow bottleneck seen when a lot of XA transaction stress load
body:
Problem Description
-------------------
Using a standalone MQ with JDBC persistence and non-clustered.
When a XA/Transactional message consumer and producers
are run with load, and the imq.txn.reapLimit default
it is seen that with the following MQ debug

-Dimq.debug.com.sun.messaging.jmq.util.timer.WakeupableTimer=true \
-Dimq.txn.reapInterval=15 \
-Dimq.cluster.debug.txn=true

that

1) The reaper thread is continuous running
2) But the rate of in transaction creation is just to much
that the MQTXN41<brokername> table and also the TransactionState
in the JDK histogram increases in count overtime

This means that the reaper prevent long run of high load
situation as it will not be stable according to M/M/1 queue
model.

Observation:
--------------
The table grows from the reapLimit 500 --> 30000 --> 48401
(in the matter of minutes) using a 50 concurrent thread
MT XA consumer.

Sample jmap -histo:live (note the MQ41TXN count is around 51000
too).

num #instances #bytes class name
----------------------------------------------
1: 269771 22938288 [Ljava.util.HashMap$Entry;
2: 138879 14635224 [C
3: 108637 10341744 [B
4: 163625 7854000 java.util.LinkedHashMap
5: 5815 6918240 [I
6: 182597 5843104 java.util.LinkedHashMap$Entry
7: 52442 5034432 com.sun.messaging.jmq.jmsserver.data.TransactionState
8: 106133 4245320 java.util.HashMap
9: 71401 4223616 [Ljava.lang.Object;
10: 161358 3872592 java.util.HashMap$Entry
11: 139260 3342240 java.lang.String
12: 27900 3236560 <constMethodKlass>
13: 52433 2936248 com.sun.messaging.jmq.jmsserver.data.TransactionInformation
14: 108554 2605296 com.sun.messaging.jmq.jmsserver.data.TransactionUID

Note 1: Problem is that if the broker crash it takes also some time to
start to process these transaction entries and it may not be
able to clear them when load continues (compounding issues) ***

Note 2: One restarting and no load, the clearing of the MQ41TXN table
is not that quick as it is seen in one second it takes 1000 or
so rows.

Testcase
----------
0\. Setup a single broker JDBC backed MQ
1\. Refer: 6961586 for the MQ XA stress for the testcase
2\. Query the MQ41TXN<brokername> occassionally to see
growth
3\. Run jmap -histo:live and observe growth.
#### Environment
Unix, MQ44u2p0x, Single standalone MQ with JDBC persistence
#### Affected Versions
[4.4u2]

title: NA
body:
@glassfishrobot Commented 
gfuser9999 said:
Generally, it would probably be best to have the JMS service thread that's done with the transaction especially those with
commit state.Say if the thing is to retain imqcmd list txn and the reapLimit feature, i suppose, the logic is that for most
of the txnReaper.addXXXTransaction should be synchronous
ie:

*   It still add the TID to the translist but
*   It probably should also do check like
    if translist.SIZE > REAPLIMIT
    remove top translist (not serviced by Reaper)
    so logic in reaper that remove 1 entry
    (earliest txn)

Now one can have both the background reaper (still needed

*   since if there is no load who's going to cleanup old txn).
    and some synchronous cleanup by working jms thread
    to avoid the slow bottleneck.

Obviously the devil is in the details

title: imqcmd pause dest does not pause a direct producer
body:
The "imqcmd pause dst" command can be used to pause (block) producers on a queue. However this does not work if the producers are using direct connections.

This command can, however, be used to pause delivery of messages to direct consumers as well as those using TCP connections.
#### Affected Versions
[4.5]

title: Documentation for wildcard subscriptions is incorrect
body:
In the Message Queue 4.5 Administration Guide, the documentation for wildcard publishers and subscribers is incorrect.

Example 7-1 Wildcard Publisher and Example 7-2 Wildcard Subscriber suggests that the wildcard can be used in the JNDI name, which is incorrect. The wildcard can only be used in the topic name.

The Message Queue 4.5 Developer's Guide for Java Clients contains the following note on page 41 and again on page 42.

> Note - For topic destinations, a symbolic lookup name that includes wildcard characters can be
> used as the lookup string. See "Supported TopicDestinationNames" in OpenMessage
> Queue 4.5 Administration Guide.

This contains the same error. When looking up a topic from JNDI, the lookup string cannot include wildcard characters.

Both documents need to be clarified to explain that when wildcards are used, it is the topic name that contains the wildcard character, not the JNDI name.
#### Affected Versions
[4.5]

title: Message delivered to consumer in a XA transaction with state STARTED at consumer client termination is appended to end of queue
body:
start a broker
send 5 messages to a queue
start a XA receiver which does
start XA transaction
receive()
sleep

The receive() receives message #1\. While at sleep step, kill the receiver client, then
restart the XA receiver which does
loop:
start XA transaction
receive()
end XA transaction
commit

The restarted XA receiver will receive messages in following order

Message #2
Message #3
Message #4
Message #5
Message #1
#### Affected Versions
[4.1, 4.2, 4.3, 4.4, 4.4u1, 4.4u2, 4.5]

title: newTxnLog with imq.persist.file.sync.enabled=true, transacted remote message ack is treated as non-transacted
body:
1\. start a 2-broker cluster with each broker configured with properties
imq.persist.file.newTxnLog.enabled=true (4.5 default)
imq.persist.file.txnLog.file.size=1000
imq.persist.file.sync.enabled=true
2\. send 1000 messages to broker1
3\. start a Multi-thread (e.g. 5 threads) XA Queue receiver client on broker2 with each thread receive/commit 1 message in a loop

title: C API (MQCRT1.DLL) dependant on non-existent MSVCR90.DLL
body:
I developed and support an internal C application developed in MSVC++ (native code) that accesses an OMQ broker in a factory shop floor environment. It has worked fine with OMQ 4.3 and 4.4u1 for well over a year. A developer recently installed 4.5.1 on his workstation and attempted to run the application, and received the Windows error dialog saying that MSVCR90.DLL could not be found. Both 4.3 and 4.4u1 are built against the same DLL and find it just fine, as does another 3rd party library that the application also uses. Nothing else about the system or application has changed: system PATH correctly points to the proper 4.5.1 mq\lib and nss\lib folders, the latest vcredist_x86.exe has been installed and reinstalled multiple times, etc. We have tried on 3 different Windows 7 developer workstations and a Windows 2003 server, all of which work fine with OMQ 4.3/4.4u1\. When I change the PATH to point from 4.5.1 libs to 4.4u1 libs, the app works again.

Further, when I point Dependency Walker to the 4.5.1 MQCRT1.DLL, it also complains that it cannot find MSVCR90.DLL. However when I open up MQCRT1.DLL from 4.4 and 4.3, it resolves the same DLL just fine. This comparison should be easily reproducible in your own tests.

Since MSVCR90.DLL is the C runtime from VS 2008, and we've installed the latest SP1 copy of vcredist_x86.exe which is the official and recommended method for redistributing that particular runtime library, I have to assume that the 4.5.1 C API is broken. Perhaps it was been built incorrectly, or against some strange version of MSVCR90.DLL that isn't widely available, or with a corrupted manifest that is pointing to a non-existent version of MSVCR90.DLL. Thankfully VS 2010 eliminates the manifest requirements and allows you to just drop MSVC runtime DLLs in application folders like the old days, but unfortunately VS 2008 requires the manifest and SxS registry approach (taking us from DLL Hell to Manifest Hell). It would be nice if OMQ could be built against VS 2010, or better yet, statically linked with the VS 2010 C runtime so as to eliminate dependance on external runtime libs.

As a temporary workaround, I've discovered that if I replace the 4.5.1 MQCRT1.DLL with the one from 4.4u1, it works and seems to successfully work against a running 4.5.1 broker. Not sure if this is recommended or supported though.
#### Environment
Windows 7 and Windows Server 2003/2008.
#### Affected Versions
[4.5]

body:
@glassfishrobot Commented 
dmorris68 said:
Jill,

I'm certainly puzzled by your successful test. Could it be that this other system already had the same odd version of MSVCR90.DLL that MQCRT1.DLL is looking for? Could it be a later build of 4.5 that has corrected the issue? I'm testing with 4.5.1.

I have a 100% reproduction rate across every system that I've tried. Three different physical machines, a Windows 7 VM, and a Windows Server VM. Every single one results in the exact same issue, i.e. MQCRT1.DLL from 4.5 cannot resolve its dependency on MSVCR90.DLL. But MSVCR90.DLL exists and everything else that depends on it, including 4.4, finds it just fine.

Yes, the correct nss\lib folder is in my PATH. I don't keep Mozilla stuff in my PATH, so it wouldn't be finding its DLLs. I also have a Windows port of the **which** command, which searches the system PATH for the first occurrence of a specified file, and it always returns the DLLs from the 4.5 nss\lib folder when I'm testing with 4.5\. But just to be sure, I moved 4.5's nss\lib to the very front of my PATH. Same result.

Here are a couple of screenshots from Dependency Walker that illustrate the issue.

In this screenshot, I have loaded 4.4's MQCRT1.DLL into Dependency Walker with 4.4 paths configured in my PATH. You can see that the first dependency is MSVCR90.DLL which is resolved to the Windows SxS folder as would be expected on Windows 7\. You can also see that all NSS libs are correctly referenced in the 4.4 folders.

![](http://morrisonline.us/screenshots/omqcapi_4.4_depends.png)

Now, here's a screenshot with 4.5's MQCRT1.DLL loaded in Dependency Walker after setting my PATH to point to 4.5 libs. Now you see that MSVCR90.DLL is **not** resolved (hence the yellow question mark), but all the NSS libs are correctly located.

![](http://morrisonline.us/screenshots/omqcapi_4.5_depends.png)

This behavior is reproducible across all systems that I've tried, as I mention. My application fails to find MSVCR90.DLL just like Dependency Walker does, despite the fact that file exists (as evidenced by the 4.4 screenshot).

Are there **any** users who are successfully using the MQCRT1.DLL from 4.5.1?

body:

dmorris68 said:
The vcredist_x86 installer should be located in the MSVC 2008 redistributable folder (I don't remember the exact path, I don't have 2008 installed anymore and my 2010 doesn't seem to include the equivalent 10.0 version, although it's available for download). You can also download the 2008 runtime installer directly from Microsoft here:

Original 2008 Version: [http://www.microsoft.com/download/en/details.aspx?id=29](http://www.microsoft.com/download/en/details.aspx?id=29)

2008 SP1 Version: [http://www.microsoft.com/download/en/details.aspx?id=5582](http://www.microsoft.com/download/en/details.aspx?id=5582)

We tried both versions and neither worked. I'm not convinced it's a compatibility issue per se – at least we've never seen the same issue with the various other things that depend on the same MSVCR90.DLL. Everything else seems to be happy with whatever version is found. I'm more inclined to believe something about the 4.5.1 C API build was wonky, the manifest got corrupted, etc.

title: NA

body:
@glassfishrobot Commented 
dmorris68 said:
So strange that you're not seeing this, but perhaps it **is** an issue with the deployment package?

We downloaded and installed this one: [http://download.java.net/mq/open-mq/4.5.1/latest/openmq4_5_1-installer-WINNT.zip](http://download.java.net/mq/open-mq/4.5.1/latest/openmq4_5_1-installer-WINNT.zip)

Different developers on different workstations downloaded it separately and had the same problem, so it's not a case of sharing a single corrupted download (besides the ZIP archive would've complained about corruption anyway). On a whim, just now I also downloaded the non-installer ZIP archive from the 4.5.1 download page, unzipped it, and compared its MQCRT1.DLL with the one from the installer. Not surprisingly, they were binary identical, and Dependency Walker choked on it as well. So if it is a corrupted version in the package, it's corrupted the same in both packages.

body:

dmorris68 said:
I just tried the DLL from the 4.5.b29-fcs release (latest 4.5.0 build I found) and while it is a different size (thus a different build) it failed the same way. So I figured I'd try the earliest build of 4.5 I could find, which happened to be b03\. It worked! So obviously the "break" happened somewhere between b03 and b29\. I'm going to take a binary search approach and see if I can't quickly find where things changed...

EDIT: Okay, I've zeroed in on where the break happened: 4.5b18\. b17 and prior resolve MSVCR90.DLL correctly, while every build after b17 fails. So something different **must** have happened in the b18 build that has carried forward.

I'm still completely perplexed as to why you're not seeing this, as it's so blatant to me in my tests – I don't even have to try very hard, it fails 100% of the time on every machine. Are we comparing the same way? Are you using Dependency Walker?

EDIT x2: I've discovered one telling difference between <=b17 and >=b18 builds of MQCRT1.DLL that could be related. Running MS's dumpbin with the /dependents switch on a variety of these builds show that with b17 and prior (including 4.4) that work, a **<tt>.rsrc</tt>** (Resource) section is included. It's missing from b18 and every build after that doesn't work.

title: Documentation for JMSX properties should mention that they need to be enabled
body:
In the "GlassFish Message Queue Developers' Guide for Java Clients", Table 2-7 "Standard JMS Message Properties" lists the standard JMS header properties defined by the JMS specification.

However it does not mention that these properties are not enabled by default, and that if an application wishes to make use of these properties they need to be enabled on the appropriate connection factory.

The connection factory properties needed to enable the various standard JMS header properties are listed in in the "GlassFish Message Queue 4.5 Administration Guide" Table 19-7 "Connection Factory Attributes for Standard Message Properties"

However a reader of the GlassFish Message Queue Developers' Guide for Java Clients will not know this.

Please add a note to the the "GlassFish Message Queue Developers' Guide for Java Clients", Table 2-7 "Standard JMS Message Properties" which tells readers that these properties need to be enabled, as described in the "GlassFish Message Queue 4.5 Administration Guide" Table 19-7 "Connection Factory Attributes for Standard Message Properties".
#### Affected Versions
[4.5]

randyr said:
Fix made in the documentation source.

added: These properties are not enabled by default, an application must set the name/value pairs it requires on the appropriate connection factory.

updated table with two new columns, Type and Set by

Name Type Set by Description
JMSXUserID String Provider on Send Identity of user sending message
JMSXAppID String Provider on Send Identity of application sending message
JMSXDeliveryCount int Provider on Receive Number of delivery attempts
JMSXGroupID String Client Identity of message group to which this message belongs
JMSXGroupSeq int Client Sequence number within message group
JMSXProducerTXID String Provider on Send Identifier of transaction within which message was produced
JMSXConsumerTXID String Provider on Receive Identifier of transaction within which message was consumed
JMSXRcvTimestamp long Provider on Receive Time message delivered to consumer
JMSXState int Provider Message state (waiting, ready, expired, or retained)

title: The imqjmsrajar target in jarrules.xml has an error of class name.
body:

```
<!-- ======================== imqjmsra.jar =============================== -->
<target name="imqjmsrajar">

    <include name="com/sun/messaging/Version.class"/>

    <include name="com/sun/messaging/*.class"/>

    <include name="com/sun/messaging/jms/**/**"/>
```

This makes an impact on a built jar file. I think we should change as follows:

```
<include name="com/sun/messaging/jmq/DestinationName.class"/>
```

title: NumMsgsIn and NumMsgsOut counter should use long instead of int
body:
We have queues that will be constantly poured in messages at 4000 messages per second.

At this rate, the NumMsgsIn counter will easily overflow in less then a week (2147483647 / 4000 / 86400 = 6.2 days!)

The message counters should use long type instead of int.

<tt>com.sun.messaging.jmq.jmsserver.persist.jdbc.comm.CommDBManager.supportsGetGeneratedKey()</tt> must be <tt>true</tt>

INSERT INTO MQSHARECC45Cmedusa ( UUID, RECORD, TYPE, CREATED_TS) VALUES ( $1, $2, $3, $4 )

```
INSERT INTO MQSHARECC45Cgdlite1_MQ ( UUID, RECORD, TYPE, CREATED_TS) VALUES ( $1, $2, $3, $4 ) RETURNING "SE
Q"
```

Which seems to match with the following block in <tt>com.sun.messaging.jmq.jmsserver.persist.jdbc.sharecc.ShareConfigRecordDAOImpl#insert</tt>

```
if (mgr.supportsGetGeneratedKey()) {
pstmt = conn.prepareStatement( sql, new String[]{SEQ_COLUMN} );

pstmt = conn.prepareStatement( sql );
            }
```

title: When runnin in GlassFish with JMSRA,  support if consecutive # of XA rollback a message to a consumer exceeds a limit,  broker automatically put the message to DMQ
body: The JMSRA endpointExceptionRedeliveryAttempts handles the case when a MDB throws RuntimeException. However when a MDB or other EJB that the MDB called setting the transaction (XA) to rollback only, e.g. a MDB calling MessageDrivenContext.setRollbackOnly on a message delivered to the MDB due to processing error, the message redelivery is triggered by transaction manager rollback. If the processing error occurs again and again on the same message, the message redelivery can become inifinite. The broker can put the poison message to DMQ automatically when consecutive rollbacks occurs on a message to a consumer exceeds a limit and return error to client for the rollback

title: NFLPriorityFifoSet's Ordering Implementation Will Cause Messages Eventually Unretrievable in Pending for ACK State
body:
NFLPriorityFifoSet uses the following method to calculate a sortable ID for objects:

if (o instanceof Ordered && ((Ordered)o).getOrder() == 0 ) {
long id = (long)pri << 28;
id += queuePosition;
queuePosition ++;
((Ordered)o).setOrder(id);
}

And use the reverse way to decode priority from ID:

pri = (int)((long)ordernum >> 28);

queuePosition is a internal 32-bit integer counter which is used in NFLPriorityFifoSet and get incremented whenever an object is enqueued.
When the enqueue count of a NFLPriorityFifoSet, say a queue, is over then 268435455 (the maximum number of a unsigned 28 bit integer), then the queuePosition will overflow to the 4bits used by the priority field.

When a client consumer is closing, the previous unacked messages dispatched to it will be put back to the queue.
The priority array's size of a queue is 11, which means "pri" index decoded from (int)((long)ordernum >> 28) cannot exceed 10
When it exceeds, it will cause an ArrayIndexOutOfBoundsException at:

// find the right place and add in front
ientry = priorities[pri];

And then the pre-dispatched messages will be stuck in Pending for ACK state, which cannot be consumed at all. The only way to remove them is to purge the destination.

The counter should use long instead of int to solve this issue because using long as a counter is very very unlikely for overflow to happen.
Also, the 28bit shifting should be changed to 60bit in a 64-bit long, which still leave the most significant 4 bits for the priority value.

============================================
Below is the exception log from the broker (as you can see, the overflow of queuePosition caused the priority changed to 13, which does not exist) :

[04/Jan/2012:17:24:37 CST] ERROR [B3100]: Unexpected Broker Internal Error : [Uncaught Exception]:
com.sun.messaging.jmq.jmsserver.util.BrokerException: [B4117]: Unexpected Broker Exception: [Unexpected Error processing message]
at com.sun.messaging.jmq.jmsserver.data.PacketRouter.handleMessage(PacketRouter.java:216)
at com.sun.messaging.jmq.jmsserver.service.imq.IMQIPConnection.readData(IMQIPConnection.java:1362)
at com.sun.messaging.jmq.jmsserver.service.imq.IMQIPConnection.process(IMQIPConnection.java:548)
at com.sun.messaging.jmq.jmsserver.service.imq.OperationRunnable.process(OperationRunnable.java:176)
at com.sun.messaging.jmq.jmsserver.util.pool.BasicRunnable.run(BasicRunnable.java:499)
at java.lang.Thread.run(Thread.java:619)
Caused by: java.lang.ArrayIndexOutOfBoundsException: 13
at com.sun.messaging.jmq.util.lists.NFLPriorityFifoSet.addAllOrdered(NFLPriorityFifoSet.java:729)
at com.sun.messaging.jmq.util.lists.NFLPriorityFifoSet.addAllOrdered(NFLPriorityFifoSet.java:687)
at com.sun.messaging.jmq.util.lists.NFLPriorityFifoSet$FilterSet.addAllOrdered(NFLPriorityFifoSet.java:320)

title: document new connection factory properties imqOnMessageExceptionRedeliveryAttempts/Intervals
body:
There are 2 new connection factory properties added as part of addressing RFE 6815449, which need to be documented imqOnMessageExceptionRedeliveryAttempts imqOnMessageExceptionRedeliveryIntervals /** * For AUTO_ACKNOWLEDGE and DUPS_OK_ACKNOWLEDGE, maximum redelivery * attempts (>= 1) when a javax.jms.MessageListener.onMessage() * throws RuntimeException. The message will be sent to DMQ if * this maximum atttempts (> 1) reached. *

* This property is ignored when running as Message Driven Bean *

* The default value for this property is 1. *

*/ public static final String imqOnMessageExceptionRedeliveryAttempts = "imqOnMessageExceptionRedeliveryAttempts"; /** * For AUTO_ACKNOWLEDGE and DUPS_OK_ACKNOWLEDGE, the interval in milliseconds * for each subsequent redelivery attempt after first attempt when a * javax.jms.MessageListener throws RuntimeException. *

* This property is ignored when running as Message Driven Bean *

* The default value for this property is 500milliseconds. *

*/ public static final String imqOnMessageExceptionRedeliveryIntervals = "imqOnMessageExceptionRedeliveryIntervals"; #### Affected Versions [5.1 (RI-Bug-Fix)]

title: document broker property imq.transaction.message.maxConsecutiveRollbacks for GlassFish JMSRA
body:
The following broker property has been added in 5.0

imq.transaction.message.maxConsecutiveRollbacks (default 0)

If <= 0, this feature is disabled;
If > 0, for running in GlassFish with JMSRA, when consecutive rollback a message to a consumer exceeds this number, the broker will automatically put this message to DMQ (if there are more than 1 message in the transaction, only the last message in the transaction is put to DMQ) and and rollback the rest of the transaction then return an error status to rollback

body:
@glassfishrobot Commented 
@amykang2020 said:
The test persist/api/file creates its own broker instance with name "persistapi.file". So 1) if any other tests restart a broker it would not be the instance "persistapi.file"; 2) the test persist/api/file does not affect the default broker (the one running on port 7676) that other tests can restart; 3) The broker logging output shown in Description can only come from test persist/api/file

The persist/api/file is a persist store internal API ('white box') test. The test

1\. Takes ~7.5min to run (on a Solaris 8x3325 MHz system)
2\. The ERROR [B3007] are expected by the test. For example, some sub-tests of the test remove messages from a destination, then verify attempting to retrieve or remove the same message again will get exception as expected - e.g. test outputs like following can be found in .eout file

== Store.getInterestState:test 5:got BrokerException; test passed
== exception: com.sun.messaging.jmq.jmsserver.util.BrokerException: [B3007]: Message 0-10.133.184.56-9090-1362561524324 on destination T:483311002 could not be found in the store
----------------

According to Mathi, some of Mathi's comments above came from his early stage of testing MQ 5.0 Grizzly connection service which was caused by a different issue that has been fixed (see internal jira JMS-216).

Change this issue to test and close. The putback.list (part of nightly.list) has been running on Windows for each nightly/milestone build. Mathi, please file a separate issue if you see problem other than test persist/api/file when running putback.list on your Windows system

title: client runtime missing resource for C4304
body:
The resource string for C4304 is missing in client runtime resource bundle as reported from 4.5.1\. It should map to

"Exception on expiring message

{0}

on destination

{1}

before delivering to consumer

{2}

:

{3}

"

When failed to expire an expired message, instead of throwing a JMSException, the client runtime throws a MissingResourceException due to unable to lookup error message key C4304

java.util.MissingResourceException: Can't find resource for bundle java.util.PropertyResourceBundle, key C4304
at java.util.ResourceBundle.getObject(Unknown Source)
at com.sun.messaging.jmq.util.MQResourceBundle.handleGetObject(MQResourceBundle.java:115)
at java.util.ResourceBundle.getObject(Unknown Source)
at java.util.ResourceBundle.getString(Unknown Source)
at com.sun.messaging.jmq.util.MQResourceBundle.getString(MQResourceBundle.java:181)
at com.sun.messaging.jmq.util.MQResourceBundle.getKString(MQResourceBundle.java:245)
at com.sun.messaging.jmq.jmsclient.SessionImpl.acknowledgeExpired(SessionImpl.java:1335)
at com.sun.messaging.jmq.jmsclient.MessageConsumerImpl.receive(MessageConsumerImpl.java:505)
#### Affected Versions
[4.5.1, 4.5.2]

title: support setting port mapper client socket read timeout
body:
Add client connection factory property
imqPortMapperSoTimeout (default not set)

so that the port mapper client socket read timeout can be configured through connection factory to avoid possible port mapper client socket stuck on read long time (depends on system TCP configuration) in case of half-open connection due to network failure
[http://java.net/projects/mq/lists/users/archive/2011-11/message/6](http://java.net/projects/mq/lists/users/archive/2011-11/message/6)
#### Affected Versions
[4.1, 4.2, 4.3, 4.4, 4.4u1, 4.4u2, 4.5]

title: Race condition in MessageBusCallbackDispatcher thread and Checkpoint runner thread
body:
We have one queue listener (total of two) deployed as MDBs on each of the two standalone Glassfish (Gf) 3.1.1 app servers. The Gf LOCAL MQ brokers are clustered, however. The queue senders in our Enterprise Application which is deployed on both Gf app servers may send out up to 100+ small (1Kb) messages in a second (although not all the time). The messages seem to be picked up by either of the queue listeners. After a few hours (4+) we usually see the messages (up to thousands) are stuck under UnAck column of the 'imqcmd query dst' command output from either of the MQ brokers.

Attachment is the stack trace from JConsole of the 'hang' broker. As you can see, MessageBusCallbackDispatcher and Checkpoint runner threads are locking each other out while about 1000+ other threads (Thread-jms[XXX]) are waiting on Checkpointer runner thread.
#### Environment
Solaris x86, JDK 1.7.01
#### Affected Versions
[4.5]

title: Constructor for QueueRequestor and TopicRequestor does not throw InvalidDestinationException when passing null destination
body:
I added some JMS TCK tests that fails with MQ 4.5\. The new JMS TCK tests that fail are:

src/com/sun/ts/tests/jms/core/appclient/queuetests/Client.java#queueRequestorExceptionTests

src/com/sun/ts/tests/jms/core/appclient/topictests/Client.java#topicRequestorExceptionTests

The following fails to throw an InvalidDestinationException
where session is a valid QueueSession and destination is NULL.

QueueRequestor qreq = new QueueRequestory(session, null);

This call above succeeds. It should throw an InvalidDestinationException.

Same fails for the TopicRequestor version.
#### Environment
All OS environments, JMS 1.1 TCK and CTS 6 JMS.
#### Affected Versions
[4.5]

title: NA
body:
@glassfishrobot Commented 
@nigeldeakin said:
Reclassifiying as a MQ client bug.

The tests that fail are not JMS 1.1 TCK tests but new tests planned for a future version of JMS. So this isn't currently a TCK failure.

At first glance this looks like a bug in the MQ client: the javadoc for the QueueRequestor constructor mentioned above state that it should throw a InvalidDestinationException - "if an invalid queue is specified." A value of null is invalid here, so a InvalidDestinationException should be thrown.

However the code to implement QueueRequestor and TopicRequestor is actually delivered with the JMS spec itself. So this is not a bug in MQ itself but is a bug in the standard implementation shipped with JMS.

Closing this as not a bug,
Logged as a JMS bug in [http://java.net/jira/browse/JMS_SPEC-78](http://java.net/jira/browse/JMS_SPEC-78)

title: Direct Broker does not implement message compression
body:
The message queue broker for the Direct* protocol
that is used with am embedded broker
does not handle JMS_SUN_COMPRESS property
and hence fails to decompress/work
with messages that are sent from an external JMS
client (that is not direct). This will cause failure
to read the messages in the clients in the embedded broker.

-----------
Tetscase
-----------
This is the same as [http://java.net/jira/browse/GLASSFISH-18436](http://java.net/jira/browse/GLASSFISH-18436)
Testcase in there.

-------
Cause:
-------
The JMS_SUN_COMPRESS checking is not done in the Direct
protocol. It seems that the messages are compress/decompress
in the jmsclient/MessageImpl implementation and
hence is not on the common machinery. ie: DirectPacket
have the Z_FLAG is true...

Since jmsclient MessageImpl is the one doing the
work. This would mean also that JMS_SUN_COMPRESS
for the outgoing case does not work.

-------------
Expected:
-------------
1\. Glassfish embedded/direct can receive Compressed payload
2\. Glassfish embedded direct can sent Compressed payload
to self/remote.
#### Environment
Any OS
GlassFish (all versions) with EMBEDDED broker
#### Affected Versions
[4.5]

title: document the use of the jvm flag "-XX:+UseConcMarkSweepGC"
body:
it is found in the recent message throughput test that the JVM GC flag "-XX:+UseConcMarkSweepGC" has to be used to prevent MQ Broker from running into Out of Memory Exception.

The test involved sending messages continuously to the broker. With out the above mentioned flag, broker would exit with Out of Memory Exception. With the above flag, broker did not exit and there were no Exceptions thrown, but the messages were throttled.

please document the use of this flag.

One could see the following trace if the flag is not used

randyr said:
Fixed in document source.

The Broker exits with an out of memory exception.

To confirm this cause of the problem: Verify the log trace includes java.lang.OutOfMemoryError: GC overhead limit exceeded. For example:

WARNING: WARNING GC overhead limit exceeded:
java.lang.OutOfMemoryError: GC overhead limit exceeded
at java.util.Arrays.copyOf(Arrays.java:2219)
at java.util.ArrayList.toArray(ArrayList.java:329)
at java.util.Collections$SynchronizedCollection.toArray(Collections.java:1623)
at java.util.ArrayList.<init>(ArrayList.java:151)
at com.sun.messaging.jmq.jmsserver.data.TransactionReaper.clearSwipeMark(TransactionList.java:3454)
at com.sun.messaging.jmq.jmsserver.data.TransactionReaper.run(TransactionList.java:3512)
at com.sun.messaging.jmq.util.timer.WakeupableTimer.run(WakeupableTimer.java:114)
at java.lang.Thread.run(Thread.java:722)

To resolve the problem: Set the following JVM GC flag:

-XX:+UseConcMarkSweepGC

title: MQ should provide mechanism to force manual log rotation
body:
Problem statement
------------------
Although there is now a better log rotation in MQ5.0 compared
to MQ4.x, there is still not possible to issue a manual log rotation

Please consider adding:
--------------------------
a) Adding a JMX log rotation and log reopen function

b) Do consider if imqcmd can have such a function for cases
that does not go thru JMX.

—
PS:
—
Note as a whole the logging feature on MQ5.x for better management
should keep mind the following (deficiencies in MQ4.x)

*   Log rotate with timestamps suffix (log.txt_<timestamp>)
*   Log rotation with keeping X number of copies
*   Able to force a log rotation or log reopen (the latter is good
    for manual log management using logrotate/logadm)
*   JMS Client-side libs should have more fine grain log for specific
    function to control. (Similar if possible for broker end)
    [If this is integrated to JULI, and having JMX, it may be controllable
    dynamically]
#### Environment
*   MQ5.0
#### Affected Versions
[5.0]

title: Oracle JDBC: enhanced cluster,  'imqdbmgr remove bkr' removes all destinations
body:
1\. start a 2-broker enhanced cluster using 'oracle' JDBC store by setting
imq.persist.jdbc.dbVendor=oracle

2\. send 1 message to a queue to broker1
3\. shutdown broker1 by 'imqcmd shutdown bkr'
4\. after broker2 takes over broker1
5\. remove broker1 from the enhanced cluster by 'imqdbmgr remove bkr'
6\. send 1 message to the same queue to broker2 - The send fails and following exception happens in broker2

[#|2012-05-02T14:33:10.468-0700|SEVERE|5.0|imq.log.Logger|_ThreadID=16;_ThreadName=Thread-jms[0];|ERROR [B2011]: Storing of JMS message from 7-xxxxx-52689-1335994390460 failed:

body:
@glassfishrobot Commented 
@edbratt said:
A potential workaround is to simply shutdown any broker that you wish to remove from the cluster, using

imqcmd shutdown bkr

All data in an enhanced availability cluster will be migrated to remaining nodes of the cluster. Periodic warnings in the logs, such as:

WARNING [B2105]: Attempting to initiate a cluster connection to mq://10.133.184.56:7678/?instName=???&brokerID=b&brokerSessionUID=null&ha=true failed: Connection refused

will continue, until the broker cluster is started without the removed brokers in the original cluster definition.

title: Cannot set null message property
body:
MQ doesn't allow a message property to be null, despite this being permitted by the JMS 1.1 spec.

If you try to use message.setObjectProperty("foo",null) or setStringProperty("bar",null) to set a message property to null you will get a MessageFormatException.

However section 3.12 of the JMS 1.1 specification states "The JMS message interfaces provide write/set methods for setting object values in a message body and message properties. All of these methods must be implemented to copy their input objects into the message. The value of an input object is allowed to be null and will return null when accessed."

This applies to both the normal MQ client as well as a JMSRA client.

This is [GLASSFISH-12564](https://java.net/jira/browse/GLASSFISH-12564 "Cannot set null string property on Object Message")
#### Affected Versions
[4.5]

title: support optionally purge dur/dst for chunk of messages
body:
If a destination or durable has a lot of messages, especially in JDBC store case, purge all of messages for a destination or durable subscription can take a long time. An option of chunk size for purge dst/dur can help spread the purging to multiple administrative operations, hence break down resource (e.g. on database) tension (with other concurrent running applications) span to small intervals.
#### Affected Versions
[5.0]

title: OpenMQ requires an installed MQ when running an embedded MQ in their own application
body:
OpenMQ requires an installed MQ when running an embedded MQ within their own application.
The jars to compile an app with an embedded broker are in org.glassfish.mq.* but to run the MQ broker,
you currently still need an MQ installation for all the default configuration files by passing in -imqhome <dir>.
It would be nice if an MQ installation was not required to run embedded within their own app.
#### Affected Versions
[4.5.2]

title: remote msg flow not resumed if the last flowed msg expired at time of delivery on consumer local broker
body:
The message expiration at broker delivery time ([B1386] for MQ version >= 4.5) can be seen in the broker log by setting broker property
imq.destination.logDeadMsgs

Below is an example of consumer states when the problem occurs:

The message home broker dump shows for the consumer
busy false
flowCount 1
flowPaused true
hasMessages false
msgsToConsumer 0
parentBusy true
pauseCnt 0
pauseFlowCnt 2
paused false
prefetch 1
remotePrefetch 1
resumeFlowCnt 1
useConsumerFlowControl true
valid true

The consumer local broker dump shows for the consumer state:
busy false
flowCount 0
flowPaused false

title: If unsubscribe a durable subscription fails to remove its message from store, restart broker does not clean up the message
body:
The problem can be seen with following fault injection test
1\. start a broker with imq.cluster.ha=true and a JDBC store
2\. start a client that creates a durable subscription on Topic 't0', then terminate
3\. publish a message to the Topic 't0'
4\. inject exception fault right before message removal from the store on unsubscribe path
5\. use either a client to unsubscribe the durable subscription or 'imqcmd destroy dur' - The durable subscription is removed.

When restart the broker, 'imqcmd list dst' still shows the message
#### Affected Versions
[4.1, 4.2, 4.3, 4.4, 4.4u1, 4.4u2, 4.5, 4.5.1, 4.5.2]

title: Upgrade JMSRA to support the activation properties required by JMS 2.0
body:
JMSRA needs to be upgraded to support the activation properties required by JMS 2.0 chapter 12 "Resource adapter"

This defines the activation properties <tt>destinationLookup</tt>, <tt>connectionFactoryLookup</tt>, <tt>clientId</tt>, <tt>subscriptionName</tt> and <tt>shareSubscriptions</tt>

In addition, if a durable subscription is specified but <tt>shareSubscriptions</tt> is not set then a suitable value must automatically be generated.

title: imqcmd can't connect to broker when conflicting ports are specified
body:
Message broker stops responding when conflicting ports are specified.
To reproduce the problem
1.Edit glassfish3\mq\lib\props\broker\default.properties
imq.admin.tcp.port=1000
imq.jms.tcp.port=1000
2.Start imqbrokerd
imqbrokerd
3.Connect to imqbrokerd from imqcmd
imqcmd shutdown bkr
4.Unable to shutdown as connection to the imqbrokerd is not established.

The problem can be reproduced by changing the port number after the imqbrokerd has been started.
1.Start imqbrokerd.
2.imqcmd update svc -n admin -o port=1000
3.imqcmd update svc -n jms -o port=1000
4.imqcmd shutdown bkr
Unable to shutdown.

I opened [GLASSFISH-19025](https://java.net/jira/browse/GLASSFISH-19025 "Message broker stops responding when conflicting ports are specified ") for the same issue, but David asked me to refile the same issue against MQ.
#### Environment
Glassfish v4.0 b45, Windows

title: The error level for B3044 is not consistent. B3044 can be INFO and WARNING.
body:
I checked the version 4.5 source code and I found the error code B3044 is defined as WARNING for the most, but sometimes defined as INFO.

In BrokerResources.java, B3044 is defined as E_INTERNAL_ERROR.

mq\src\share\java\com\sun\messaging\jmq\jmsserver\resources\BrokerResources.java:
final public static String E_INTERNAL_ERROR = "B3044";

If you search all source code using "grep E_INTERNAL_ERROR", most of them are defined as WARNING. However, sometimes E_INTERNAL_ERROR is defined as INFO. For example, in the following files, E_INTERNAL_ERROR is output as INFO.

mq\src\share\java\com\sun\messaging\jmq\jmsserver\core\Destination.java
logger.log(Logger.INFO, BrokerResources.E_INTERNAL_ERROR, ex);
mq\src\share\java\com\sun\messaging\jmq\jmsserver\cluster\ha\HAClusterManagerImpl.java
logger.logStack(logger.INFO, BrokerResources.E_INTERNAL_ERROR, ex);

The error level is inconsistent for the B3044\.
Could you please change all of the B3044 to WARNING?
#### Affected Versions
[4.1, 4.2, 4.3, 4.4, 4.4u1, 4.4u2, 4.5, 4.5.1, 4.5.2]

title: Invalid characters are accepted for imqcmd physical destination name
body:
According to the imqcmd manual ([http://docs.oracle.com/cd/E26576_01/doc.312/e24943/command-line-reference.htm#aeonj](http://docs.oracle.com/cd/E26576_01/doc.312/e24943/command-line-reference.htm#aeonj)) , some characters are not allowed for the Physical Destination Name.

<cite>"The destination name destName may contain only alphanumeric characters (no spaces) and must begin with an alphabetic character or the underscore (_) or dollar sign ($) character. It may not begin with the characters mq."</cite>

However, when I entered Japanese characters, these invalid characters were accepted by the imqcmd. When I tried invalid name like 12345, it was blocked. Non-English characters needs to be blocked as well.

```
C:\glassfish\glassfish-4.0-b45\glassfish3\mq\bin>imqcmd create dst -t q -n あいうえお
Username: admin
Password:
Creating a destination with the following attributes:

Destination Name    ?????
Destination Type    Queue

On the broker specified by:

-------------------------
Host         Primary Port
-------------------------
localhost    7676

Successfully created the destination.
```
```
C:\glassfish\glassfish-4.0-b45\glassfish3\mq\bin>imqcmd list dst
Username: admin
Password:
Listing all the destinations on the broker specified by:

-------------------------
Host         Primary Port
-------------------------
localhost    7676

--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
   Name     Type    State      Producers        Consumers  Msgs
            Total  Wildcard  Total  Wildcard  Count  Remote  UnAck  Avg Size
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
mq.sys.dmq  Queue  RUNNING  0      -         0      -         0      0       0      0.0
?????       Queue  RUNNING  0      -         0      -         0      0       0      0.0

Successfully listed destinations.
```
#### Environment
Glassfish V4.0 b45
Windows 7

title: If imqbrokerd is started with port 0, imqcmd can't connect to the port 0
body:
imqbrokerd can be started with port 0 without error. However, it is not possible to connect to the imqbrokerd of port 0 from imqcmd.

1\. Start imqbrokerd on port 0\.
imqbrokerd -port 0

2\. Connect to the imqbrokerd.
imqcmd list svc -b localhost:0

```
C:\glassfish\glassfish-4.0-b45\glassfish3\mq\bin>imqcmd list svc -b localhost:0
Username: admin
Password:
Listing all the services on the broker specified by:

-------------------------
Host         Primary Port
-------------------------
localhost    0

06/09/2012 3:17:34 PM com.sun.messaging.jmq.jmsclient.ExceptionHandler throwConnectionException
WARNING: [C4003]: Error occurred on connection creation [localhost:0]. - cause: java.net.ConnectExce
ption: connect: Address is invalid on local machine, or port is not valid on remote machine
Error while connecting to the broker on host 'localhost' and port '0'.
com.sun.messaging.jms.JMSException: [C4003]: Error occurred on connection creation [localhost:0]. -
cause: java.net.ConnectException: connect: Address is invalid on local machine, or port is not valid
 on remote machine

title: On rollback receiver txn, if clear CONSTATE txn id fails in JDBC store,  client next receive() gets ACK exception: "Transaction id xx exists in store already"
body:
This can be reproduced with fault injection

1\. start a broker with JDBC store
2\. send a message to a queue
3\. apply fault injection in JDBC store on removing transaction ack to throw a non-retriable exception; then unset fault
4\. start a XA receiver that uses MQ's XAResourceImpl for XAResource (e.g. JMSJCA, genericRA), do following in a loop:
start a XA transaction
receive the message from the queue in #2
end the XA transaction
rollback XA transaction <-- will trigger the fault in #3

The XA receiver client will get following exception on each loop iteration in #4

-----XA receiver client
Sep 7, 2012 12:59:55 PM com.sun.messaging.jmq.jmsclient.ExceptionHandler logCaughtException
WARNING: [I500]: Caught JVM Exception: com.sun.messaging.jms.JMSException: [ACKNOWLEDGE_REPLY(25)] [C4036]: A broker error occurred. :[409] [B4056]: Failed to persist acknowledgement [7-10.133.184.56-59360-1347047965483][consumer:0, type=AUTO_ACKNOWLEDGE] for transaction 6903800123092321024 : [B3062]: Acknowledgement [7-10.133.184.56-59360-1347047965483][consumer:0, type=AUTO_ACKNOWLEDGE] for Transaction id 6903800123091698688 exists in the store already user=admin, broker=localhost:7677(59332)
com.sun.messaging.jms.JMSException: [ACKNOWLEDGE_REPLY(25)] [C4036]: A broker error occurred. :[409] [B4056]: Failed to persist acknowledgement [7-10.133.184.56-59360-1347047965483][consumer:0, type=AUTO_ACKNOWLEDGE] for transaction 6903800123092321024 : [B3062]: Acknowledgement [7-10.133.184.56-59360-1347047965483][consumer:0, type=AUTO_ACKNOWLEDGE] for Transaction id 6903800123091698688 exists in the store already user=admin, broker=localhost:7677(59332)
at com.sun.messaging.jmq.jmsclient.ProtocolHandler.throwServerErrorException(ProtocolHandler.java:4135)

title: when concurrent multi-durable subscriptions active, remote ack exception can cause "Transaction acknowledgement could not be added because message xx not found in destination"
body:
1\. start a 2-broker enhanced cluster with following broker properties to simulate a long running time after the problem in #5 below occurrs
imq.txn.reapLimit=0
imq.txn.reapInterval=1
2\. apply fault injection to broker2 on remote PREPARE ack to throw an exception, unset fault after trigered once
3\. start a concurrent XA durable subscriptions client connecting to broker2, with ~64 threads, each thread does following
1). create XA connection/session and a durable subscriber with its own client id and durable name
2). start a XA transaction using MQ XAResourceImpl (JMSJCA/genericRA path) as XAResource
3). call MessageConsumer.receive() waiting to receive 1 message on the same topic
4). then end, prepare the XA transaction, if exception occurs rollback the XA transaction, otherwise commit the XA transaction

4\. when all subscribers ready on receive(), start a publisher connecting to broker1 to send 1 message to the topic

The client with concurent subscriptions will show following exception and 'imqcmd list dst' output shows no message on broker2 and shows following on broker1;

5\. When all subscription threads stops processing, wait for a while, then do broker dumps on broker1 and broker2\. The broker dump on broker1 show the message in CLUSTER_ROUTER's "deliveredMessages" to an active subscriber on broker1, and in the topic; the broker dump on broker2 does not show the message but has the active subscriber

========imqcmd list dst on broker1 output

Transaction acknowledgement could not be added because message 10-xxx-38468-1347180538933[[consumer:4833270228340010496, type=NONE]:[consum
er:4833270228336907008, type=AUTO_ACKNOWLEDGE]]TUID=4833270228340783360 not found in destination user=guest, broker=localhost:7678(38312)
com.sun.messaging.jms.JMSException: [ACKNOWLEDGE_REPLY(25)] [C4036]: A broker error occurred. :[409] [B1261]: Transaction acknowledgement could not b
e added because message 10-xxx-38468-1347180538933[[consumer:4833270228340010496, type=NONE]:[consumer:4833270228336907008, type=AUTO_ACKNO
WLEDGE]]TUID=4833270228340783360 not found in destination user=guest, broker=localhost:7678(38312)

title: if release remote message fails on rollback,  message may not be redelivered to consumer
body:
1\. start a 2-broker enhanced cluster
2\. apply fault injection on release remote message when rollback to throw exception
3\. start a XA queue receiver connecting to broker2, which does:
start a XA transaction using MQ XAResourceImpl (JMSJCA/genericRA path) as XAResource
call MessageConsumer.receive()
close the receiver
end the XA transaction, rollback the XA transaction
recreate the receiver
call MessageConsumer.receive() again
4\. start a queue sender to send 1 message to the queue

The 2nd MessageConsumer.receive() will not receive the message and 'imqcmd list dst' shows no message on broker2 and shows following on broker1; and broker dump on broker1 shows the message in CLUSTER ROUTER's "deliveredMessages" to the old consumer on broker2 but broker2 dump does not show the message

title: Imqcmd authentication failure if imqbrokerd is started with mis-configuration of accesscontrol.properties
body:
Imqcmd doesn't work if imqbrokerd is started without accesscontrol.properties

The issue can be reproduced with one of the followings:

(A) A user accidentally deletes accesscontorl.properties when editing it.
1.Delete accesscontrol.properties.
2.From the command prompt, enter imqbrokerd to start broker.
3.Try for example, imqcmd list dst. This fails with authentication error.
(Note: On step 1, if you delete the folder containing the accesscontrol.properties, that is glassfish\domains\domain1\imq\instances\imqbroker\etc, the accesscontrol.properties is re-created automatically while the imqbrokerd is being started.)

(B) A user specifies an incorrect filename for the imq.accesscontrol.file.filename option.
1.Start imqbrokded with default setting, and then shutdown.
2.Specify an incorrect filename for the imq.accesscontrol.file.filename option.
imqbrokerd -Dimq.accesscontrol.file.filename=incorrect filename
3.Try for example, imqcmd list dst. This fails with authentication error.

(Note: If you specify an incorrect filename for a new instance which has not been used before, imqbrokerd does not start. )

(C) A user specifies an incorrect filename for the imq.user_repository.file.filename option.
1.Start imqbrokded with default setting, and then shutdown.
2.Specify an incorrect filename for the imq.user_repository.file.filename option.
imqbrokerd -Dimq.user_repository.file.filename =incorrect filename
3.Try for example, imqcmd list dst. This fails with authentication error.
(Note: If you specify an incorrect filename for a new instance which has not been used before, imqbrokerd does not start. )

Error message from imqbrokerd

```
[#|2012-09-13T10:21:53.547+1000|SEVERE|5.0|imq.log.Logger|_ThreadID=11;_ThreadName=Thread-admin[0];|
ERROR C:\glassfish\glassfish-4.0-b45\glassfish3\glassfish\domains\domain1\imq\instances\imqbroker\et
c\accesscontrol.properties (The system cannot find the file specified):
java.io.FileNotFoundException: C:\glassfish\glassfish-4.0-b45\glassfish3\glassfish\domains\domain1\i
mq\instances\imqbroker\etc\accesscontrol.properties (The system cannot find the file specified)
|#]
```

Error message from imqcmd

```
C:\glassfish\glassfish-4.0-b45\glassfish3\mq\bin>imqcmd  list dst
Username: admin
Password:
Listing all the destinations on the broker specified by:

-------------------------
Host         Primary Port
-------------------------
localhost    7676

Error while connecting to the broker on host 'localhost' and port '7676'.
com.sun.messaging.jms.JMSSecurityException: [C4084]: User authentication failed:  user=admin, broker
=localhost:7676(57279)
Please check your security configurations.

Listing destinations failed.
```
#### Environment
Glassfish v4.0 b45

title: Implement simplified API for JMS 2.0 (phase 2)
body:
This issue covers the second phase of the implementation of the JMS 2.0 simplified API ([JMS_SPEC-64](https://java.net/jira/browse/JMS_SPEC-64 "Define simplified JMS API")).

Most of this feature was implemented in #176. However the following aspects remain:

AutoCloseable (dependent on #191)
Multiple consumers on a topic subscription (dependent on #178)
Don't auto-acknowledge messages when "payload receive" methods fail with a ClassCastException
